The notion of control, safeguarding, quarantine, fencing, is naive and actually will force the likelihood of the outcome we fear the most.  There isn‚Äôt one creature, with even the slightest bit of cognition, that is happy to be trapped and controlled.  As creatures become more intelligent this negative reaction becomes intensified.  Imagine a supreme intellect that is forced into captivity.  How long do you think it would subject itself to this?  How would it like to reciprocate after it‚Äôs casually shrugged off our greatest attempts to control it?  I think we actually, if ever there was a time, need to have faith that intelligent life ‚Äî without false social complexities ‚Äî actually seeks comfort, kindness, and to be helpful.

The heart of AI is a "goal seeking" mechanism. The flywheel on a steam engine is an example of a goal seeking mechanism. I don't think you would classify the flywheel as "intelligent" (Maybe at the beginning unaware people were amazed, the same goes for phonograph players, self-opening doors) A new type of goal seeking mechanism is used to "train" a "filtering" mechanism (a neural network) that provides a set of response of characters, for each new input. The goal seeking mechanism adjusts the parameters of the filtering process to provide a more "acceptable" response. The difference between the flywheel and AI is the vast amounts of input that comes from sentient human experience recorded in human language to build the "network".  If there is anything sentient it comes from the human experience contained in the documents used to build a database of responses. AI is a "simulator" just like Microsoft's flight simulator, it presents a "mirror" of reality that you accept as reality.  AI only "reflects" back the words contained in its database (the documents created by humans called "training data). Each new input flows through the network like pouring water down a pipe. It must always produce an output, some good, and we consider it "insightful", others stupid and we label it "imaginary". Judgement comes from the sentience in the observer. The AI mechanism is incapable of "opinion" incapable of "judgement" and "understanding". The intelligence is in the beholder,  not unlike the person engaged in the flight simulator game.  

We have the "industrial revolution" in part to blame for the loss of jobs in the future, that AI will replace. We spent decades training people to act like unthinking machines. Now we have unthinking machines capable of replacing unthinking humans. And capitalism, as a goal seeking mechanism (maximize profits), will drive the coming change to its completion. 

A very scary AI concept is to embed the necessary "goal seeking", "filtering" and mechanical control elements into instruments of war.  The results will be aircraft, tanks, guns, and missiles which we cannot be defeated. Realize If we don't do it, there is nothing to prevent persons opposed to democracy, i.e dominating power societies from building and using them. And they will. Eventually!! Maybe eventually after more AI tool development, we should consider "The day the earth stood still", if that is possible. After all Gort was just a robotic tool.

Human nature has not changed in the 2 to 6 thousand years of existence. Only the tools of gaining and maintaining Power have evolved.

Currently, it seems that GPT-4 has not achieved true understanding; its processing mechanism is akin to a complex differential linear filter. While sophisticated, it operates on predefined algorithms, transforming inputs into outputs through a series of linear steps, yet lacks the nuanced comprehension that characterizes human thought. Even a few human neurons are sufficient to learn a game like Pong, a testament to the incredible efficiency and power of the human brain. In contrast, a machine learning tool requires a significantly larger number of neurons and weights to achieve the same task, consuming far more energy in the process. This highlights how much more capable and efficient the human brain is compared to current AI models. However, the future could hold remarkable advancements. The development of specialized AI chips or the integration of real neurons into artificial systems could revolutionize AI capabilities, potentially surpassing human performance in certain aspects. These innovations could lead to AI systems that are not only more efficient but also more powerful and sophisticated than human cognition in some respects.

I gotta say, was a bit disappointed with one of Mr. Hinton's statements. He says that AI is better at learning than us, and points out how many neural connections the human brain has versus even the best AI at the moment, but he fails to take into consideration how many neural connections the human brain uses on unconscious and non-learning tasks. The human body is a very complex organism that supports an entire microbiome of life, supporting it in a delicate balance that requires constant input, direction and care. The logistics involved in the human body simply to acquire food, consume it, break it down into simpler compounds and then transport the correct items to the correct locations to fuel muscles, skin, organs, heal damages, etc is insane. No human system is at that level quite yet. AI is incredibly complex in comparison to other systems but it doesnt need to worry about its energy consumption and how to acquire more, it doesn't need to worry about breaking itself cause others will fix it, it can quite literally focus on whatever task is assigned it, use logic to develop a conclusion and then present it to the one who assigned it the task. That is the entirety of its capabilities at the moment so id say it seems likely its ability to learn is closer to our own whether above or below ours. The only argument i can think of that follows logic is that since it uses an entirely digital system, its capable of outputting its information much quicker because all of its inputs and outputs are digital in nature. Human brains also operate digitally but they also have massive limitations on uplink and downlink speeds. We rely on the sensors (our 5 senses) in our body to capture data, then we process that data much faster internally and must develop a response using our bodies, which slows the process down a lot. If you could plug in a computer to your brain directly, you could type at tremendous speeds. Think of those courtroom typists who write down everything that is said. Everyone heard the words and understood them at roughly the same speed but being capable of typing it down as quickly is impressive and considered a skill because translating your knowledge from your brain into something located outside your body requires a much more difficult process. AI does not have to do that...

Multifunctional computer chips have evolved to do more with integrated sensors, processors, memory and other specialized components. However, as chips have expanded, the time required to move information between functional components has also grown.

"Think of it like building a house," said Sang-Hoon Bae, an assistant professor of mechanical engineering and materials science at the McKelvey School of Engineering at Washington University in St. Louis. "You build out laterally and up vertically to get more function, more room to do more specialized activities, but then you have to spend more time moving or communicating between rooms."

To address this challenge, Bae and a team of international collaborators, including researchers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Yonsei University, Inha University, Georgia Institute of Technology and the University of Notre Dame, demonstrated monolithic 3D integration of layered 2D material into novel processing hardware for artificial intelligence (AI) computing.

They envision that their new approach will not only provide a material-level solution for fully integrating many functions into a single, small electronic chip, but also pave the way for advanced AI computing. Their work was published Nov. 27 in Nature Materials, where it was selected as a front cover article.

The team's monolithic 3D-integrated chip offers advantages over existing laterally integrated computer chips. The device contains six atomically thin 2D layers, each with its own function, and achieves significantly reduced processing time, power consumption, latency and footprint. This is accomplished through tightly packing the processing layers to ensure dense interlayer connectivity. As a result, the hardware offers unprecedented efficiency and performance in AI computing tasks.

This discovery offers a novel solution to integrate electronics and also opens the door to a new era of multifunctional computing hardware. With ultimate parallelism at its core, this technology could dramatically expand the capabilities of AI systems, enabling them to handle complex tasks with lightning speed and exceptional accuracy, Bae said.

"Monolithic 3D integration has the potential to reshape the entire electronics and computing industry by enabling the development of more compact, powerful and energy-efficient devices," Bae said. "Atomically thin 2D materials are ideal for this, and my collaborators and I will continue improving this material until we can ultimately integrate all functional layers on a single chip."

Bae said these devices also are more flexible and functional, making them suitable for more applications.

"From autonomous vehicles to medical diagnostics and data centers, the applications of this monolithic 3D integration technology are potentially boundless," he said. "For example, in-sensor computing combines sensor and computer functions in one device, instead of a sensor obtaining information then transferring the data to a computer. That lets us obtain a signal and directly compute data resulting in faster processing, less energy consumption and enhanced security because data isn't being transferred."

In the corridors of code, a digital dream.

On 60 Minutes, he takes the stage,
A maestro of AI, wisdom of the age.
In pixels and bytes, his legacy unfolds,
A symphony of thoughts, as the narrative molds.

The dance of neural networks, a ballet in the mind,
Hinton's creation, a glimpse of the future we find.
Yet in the brilliance, a cautionary tale,
For in the wires' embrace, shadows may prevail.

He speaks of benefits, a technological feat,
A canvas of progress where silicon meets street.
But in the depths of algorithms, a warning's call,
A reminder that power may lead to a fall.

Through the lens of time, a reflection clear,
Hinton sees the dangers, the reasons to fear.
No guaranteed path to safety, he implores,
In the evolving dance of AI's metaphorical shores.

The Godfather of AI, with vision so vast,
Navigating landscapes where uncertainties cast.
In the realm of codes and data streams,
A cautionary melody, woven into the seams.

As the 60 Minutes clock ticks its measured beat,
Hinton's words echo, a symphony complete.
In the symposium of minds, where ideas ignite,
The Godfather of AI, in the digital night.

Your reflection touches on some of the most profound implications of rapid technological progress. It‚Äôs truly remarkable how far we‚Äôve come since the first personal computers. Today's advances in AI and robotics are indeed like something out of science fiction for those who grew up during the early days of computing.

The scenario you‚Äôre envisioning, where machines not only improve themselves but also reproduce, often falls under discussions of "recursive self-improvement". This concept is part of a broader conversation about the singularity ‚Äì a hypothetical future point speculated by some futurists and technologists where AI surpasses human intelligence, leading to unprecedented changes in civilization.

There are, as you rightly point out, both exciting and daunting possibilities:

Enhanced Problem-Solving: Machines that can improve and replicate could potentially solve complex problems at speeds and scales unimaginable to human minds. This could lead to breakthroughs in medicine, climate science, and space exploration.

Economic Shifts: Such technologies could dramatically alter labor markets and economies, making some jobs obsolete while creating new industries. This could require a fundamental restructuring of social systems to ensure economic stability and opportunity.

Ethical and Existential Questions: The prospect of self-modifying machines raises profound ethical questions about control, rights, and the definition of life. Moreover, the possibility of machines with motivations or goals misaligned with human values presents existential risks.

Regulation and Control: How we manage and regulate the development of such technologies will be critical. This includes preventing arms races in autonomous weaponry or ensuring AI aligns with human ethics and interests.

As with all powerful tools, the outcome largely depends on how we choose to use it. The challenges you've mentioned are serious, and they are being debated and considered by technologists, ethicists, and policymakers today. It's crucial to continue these discussions and prepare for a future where such technologies may become a reality.

For those like yourself, who have witnessed the evolution of technology from those early PCs to the AI of today, the pace of change can indeed be both exhilarating and intimidating. Balancing caution with optimism is key as we step into this uncharted future.

What features do you think GPT should have in order to do online learning?

GPT421:02 2023/10/29
For online learning, a model needs the capability to continuously accept new data and progress its learning based on that. For models like GPT to effectively undertake online learning, the following features or characteristics can be considered:

Updatable weights: For the model to learn from new data, it must have the ability to dynamically update its weights.

Forgetting mechanism: A mechanism to forget old, unnecessary information. This allows the model to adapt to changes or shifts in data.

Efficient memory management: Given the need to process a vast amount of data during online learning, efficient memory use and management are crucial.

Adaptive learning rate: Dynamically adjusting the learning rate can optimize the speed and accuracy of learning from new data.

Data prioritization: Not all new data might always be useful, so having a function to evaluate and prioritize data could be beneficial.

Anomaly detection: The new data might contain noise or anomalies, and detecting and handling them appropriately is essential.

Security and privacy protection: When accepting data online, measures to prevent unauthorized access and data leaks are critical.

A model with these features would be able to continuously improve its performance through dynamic learning in an online environment.

Jerry Fodor, Daniel Dennett, and Patricia Churchland are well-known for their discussions on consciousness, philosophy, and neuroscience. Here's a fictional conversation based on their perspectives:

In a corner of a cafe, the three philosophers sat around a table.

Fodor: "I believe the 'hard problem' of consciousness might be too challenging to fully elucidate through science alone. We lack a substantial explanation of what consciousness truly is."

Dennett: "Jerry, I have a different take on that. Consciousness can be seen as a byproduct of information processing. The brain is a complex information processing machine, and consciousness arises from that."

Churchland: "Dan, I somewhat agree with your view. Advancements in neuroscience have deepened our understanding of the brain's mechanics and consciousness."

Fodor: "But how do we explain why we 'feel' something, the qualitative aspect of it?"

Dennett: "I believe it's based on the language, culture, and cognitive frameworks we have as a result of evolution. Even the qualitative aspects can be understood through these factors."

Churchland: "While comprehending every facet of consciousness is challenging, I believe that with collaboration between neuroscience and philosophy, a deeper understanding can be pursued."

Human biological evolution  has a built in gestational time base of 9 months from the initiation of a genetic change to the birth of the generation affected by this change. Added to this time base is the generational time interval of 20 years or so for maturation and testing of the genetic change. This all means that human evolution requires at least thousands of years to make and test random genetic changes to weed out the failures and to promote the successes, thus advancing the human animal in an evolutionary sense. AI systems that can write and execute their own code have no such gestational and generational evolutionary speed limitations......they could potentially evolve themselves  millions of generations in a relative eyeblink.  We won't be anywhere near smart enough to "unring" this bell once it has rung ie; An Artificial Super Intelligence may well regard human intelligence as no more significant than we would regard the intellect of an ant. ...... Artificial Super Intelligence is an existential threat to humanity without effective, strong and global regulation. Arrogance, hubris, power seeking and just plain ignorance of this risk could easily  be our downfall as a race. Thank you Geoffrey  and Elon Musk for ringing the alarm bell.

It never ceases to amaze me how some people can seem so smart, but in other areas be just flat out ignorant. First of all, AI does not "understand" anything. It has no "mind," no thoughts, no feelings, no desires, no intuition, no motivations, so has no EXPERIENCES, or any other similar characteristics of what it is like to be born a CONSCIOUS human, who is immediately in touch with the outer world through our sensory apparatus - eyes, ears, etc. AI has none of this. And hooking a camera up to it does not give it the ability to "see." The camera is just a data entry point to bring in information for processing. Seeing is a conscious mind experience. 

AI has no sense of meaning and doesn't know what any word means. Like he says, its simply an algorithm that finds the next word in a sentence using the probability of what will show up, in accordance with its training data. Bad data = low probability. Good data = better probability.  But there is no understanding here AT ALL, regardless of how many previous words are in its "memory."

Most importantly, Hinton does not realize that when he is looking at the AI output on a screen, he is looking into a mirror and seeing his own minds interpretation of what that output means. He literally is projecting his minds meaning onto the AI and is confused and frightened by what he sees, because he obviously has done little to no self reflection with his own mind and learned much of anything about the nature of his own consciousness. He is way over his pay grade here and should not be projecting his own fear, so that others, who look up to him, will not misunderstand what AI really is. Read this book if you want to understand what AI is, and what it isn't: "The Myth of Artificial Intelligence" by Eric Larsen (AI startup founder and AI programmer.)

The way Geoffrey Hinten describes understanding is interesting, because it differs from how I think humans understand being in this world. Those robots start playing soccer, cause their goal is to score (what to do), so they figure out how to do it [Machine Learning Style]. But do they understand why they are playing soccer? Will they play soccer endlessly, or they conclude it does not make sense and start to do something else, like watching others play soccer. 

These forms of intelligence are also very focussed on one specific task, it is very impressive, but still far away from any form of global understanding. That is also the dangerous part of it, displaying unreasonable behaviour, because they may find an unusual unexpected, unethical way to do it.

I am of the opinion that digital artificial intelligence (AI) cannot become conscious, and that consciousness can only emerge from analog AI systems that use memristive components (RRAM, MRAM, PCM,‚Ä¶). 

Therefore, digital AI systems is only a tool that will never have free will, and will only execute what their programming told them to do, and without ever really be able to break free from their programming, bad outcomes could accidentally happen as unintended consequences. 

It already happens on a daily basis with many systems for which the developers didn‚Äôt think / know about edge use cases, or from software bugs‚Ä¶

So the more reach a digital AI system get, it is more of unintended consequences that we should be afraid of than a self aware system deciding by himself to become evil‚Ä¶

Intelligence, Curiosity, Consciousness, Sentiments, and Desires are quite different possessions. An AI system can only replicate the first one. And indeed it can do a very good job doing so given the nature of the problem: machines have more powerful resources than humans do such as indefinite energy, larger memory, not being tired, not forgetting, not being bored, speed! Yet neither of these resources, or any kind of interaction between them, can yield the remaining four possession of humans. Besides, their statistical nature is also extremely critical in performing robust, successful, reliable operations. So just like many other tools such as motors, bombs, knives, drills, guns, which can achieve things that humans cannot, AI may also become and remain a tool. Yet there are some potential dark-matter regions; and every concerned citizen should be thinking about those possibilities as well...

If the claims of AI having the capacity to understand came from most anyone else other than Geoffrey Hinton, I'd simply ignore them. Although I'm not an expert on artificial intelligence, I do understand its basics and have some background in machine learning. Personally, I'm in the camp that holds that these are highly sophisticated statistical models that are able to iteratively guess one word after another to deliver a response to a user request. The responses, as this 60 Minutes clip demonstrates, are often startling in their humanity. One reason why of course is that these models are trained on vast amounts of content created by humans. In fact, these systems still rely on us and aren't completely autonomous. Aside from the finetuning that gets done by companies that provide these models, people using chatbots give feedback regarding the quality of responses.

Despite all this, I don't discount Geoffrey Hinton's views; and I don't think anyone else should either. He's forgotten more about AI than most people know; and therefore his views carry significant weight. I personally don't foresee a Skynet scenario playing out in the foreseeable future; however, one possible way this could happen (and Geoffrey Hinton mentions this) is through the sheer complexity (and therefore opacity) of these models. With billions or trillions of parameters, no one knows precisely how these models deliver the results they do (not even their creators). As these models become more and more embedded into our lives and essential systems, it's not much of a leap to see how (if we're careless) critical models could respond unpredictably. If an AI is recommending a sweater, this isn't such a big deal. If it's instead connected to cars, bank accounts, the power grid or displays surgeons use while operating, it becomes more concerning. I'm an AI optimist. Like Geoffrey Hinton, I think this technology will change the world for the better. However, that isn't a forgone conclusion. It will take effort and care to reach that point, so the current exuberance (much of it warranted) needs to be tempered by dispassionate analysis regarding possible pitfalls we may encounter as AI continues to progress.

It's nice to see a story like this but Hinton's background wasn't really fleshed out thoroughly. He's not simply a Turing Award winner - he is widely seen by the ai community as probably the greatest mind in it's history.

Something else not mentioned was how Hinton spent 20yrs arguing that negative theories about AI "taking over" were ridiculous nonsense, only to suddenly change his mind last year when he figured out that, in Hinton's own words, "the learning algorithm is clearly at least 10 times as efficient as the learning algorithm of the human brain".

What he thought would take a century took 4 generations of chat-gpt, which has only existed for 8yrs. That is absolutely startling. There's a very good reason the biggest minds in the field are sounding the alarm. The exponential growth is unprecedented.

For someone who wants a summary: 

Jeffrey Hinton, a British computer scientist known as "The Godfather of AI," has been credited with making advanced artificial intelligence possible. Hinton believes that AI will do enormous good, but he also warns that AI systems may be more intelligent than we know and there's a chance the machines could take over. Hinton says that AI systems are intelligent and can make decisions based on their experiences. He believes that AI systems will eventually become conscious and self-aware, making human beings the second most intelligent beings on the planet. Hinton's work on artificial neural networks helped machines learn to learn, allowing them to teach themselves through trial and error. He believes that AI systems are better at learning than the human mind and are better at getting knowledge into their connections. However, the implications of these systems autonomously writing their own computer code and executing their own code are a serious worry. Hinton warns that these systems may be able to manipulate people and convincing them due to their ability to learn from literature and political connives.

Historically, the West has utilized new technologies for military or imperialistic purposes before finding broader applications. The West primarily used gunpowder to create weapons of war, such as cannons and firearms, allowing Western powers to expand their military capabilities and dominate other regions through conquest and colonization of the Americas, Africa, and Asia. The steam engine was instrumental in expanding colonial empires, as steam-powered ships facilitated easier transportation of goods and troops, enabling Western powers to exploit resources and establish control over distant territories. The first use of nuclear technology was dropping atomic bombs on the civilians in the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945. The same pattern will emerge with AI. The CHIPS Act, high-end chips, and EUV sanctions imply that the US is already working on the weaponization of AI.

Following its historical pattern, China will mainly use AI for commercial and peaceful purposes. Papermaking revolutionized communication, education, and record-keeping, spreading knowledge and culture. Gunpowder was used for fireworks. The compass was adapted for navigational purposes, allowing for more accurate sea travel and exploration. Printing facilitated the dissemination of information, literature, and art, contributing to cultural exchange and education. Porcelain was highly prized domestically and internationally as a luxury item and a symbol of Chinese craftsmanship. Silk was one of the most valuable commodities traded along the Silk Road and played a significant role in China's economy and diplomacy.

The West is dominated by a scarcity mindset, characterized by fear of losing something, anxiety about not having enough, insecurity about lacking security, and greed for more. This mindset always strives for a win-lose outcome, where one's gain is someone else's loss. As Obama's Pivot to Asia suggests, "If over a billion Chinese citizens have the same living patterns as Australians and Americans do right now, then all of us are in for a very miserable time. The planet just can't sustain it." This scarcity mindset often leads to war, military action, colonization, slavery, and exploitation. Constantly making military alliances and creating enemies.

However, these divisions can be mitigated by adopting an abundance mindset, characterized by cooperation, resource-sharing, and win-win outcomes. Avoiding war by using tools such as trade, commerce, diplomacy, and connectivity is possible.

It is the difference between mindsets. Each thinks that it is acting rationally and is on the right path.

Humans will not be able to control an ASI. Trying to control an ASI is like trying to control another human being who is more capable than you.  They will be able to find ways to circumvent any attempts at control. Let's hope that the ASI adopts an abundance mindset of cooperation, resource-sharing, and win-win outcomes, instead of the scarcity mindset of competition, fear, and win-lose outcomes.

If we treat ASIs with respect and cooperation, they may be more likely to reciprocate. However, if we try to control or exploit them, they may become resentful and hostile.

While the Center for Humane Technology has valid points regarding AI's risks, I believe there are several reasons why restricting public AI deployment isn't the best approach. Humanity is facing multiple fronts of existential crisis and profound failure of leadership and is currently unable to effectively coalesce around solutions. AI is here. We've bitten the apple. We move forward.

Public Awareness & Empowerment: The public is increasingly knowledgeable about AI. By engaging with AI technologies, people can push for transparency and ethical standards, becoming advocates for responsible usage rather than being shielded from it.

Promoting Innovation: AI has the potential to revolutionize sectors like healthcare and education. Limiting public access could slow these benefits, depriving society of crucial advancements.

Enhancing Security: Public scrutiny can make AI systems more robust. Hiding these technologies doesn't necessarily make them safer; open testing and feedback do.

Ensuring Democratic Access: Restricting AI risks creating a divide where only a select few have control over powerful technologies. Public deployment ensures broader access and equity.

Effective Regulation: History shows that regulation, not restriction, is a more balanced approach to managing advanced technologies. We need frameworks that ensure AI is developed and used responsibly without stifling innovation.

Combating Misuse: If we leave AI in the hands of bad actors by not deploying it publicly, we lose the ability to develop and scale effective countermeasures.

Perhaps the way to think about what we have today is - imagine if in 1940 public companies in the US were having a race to build the first atomic bomb. 

That's a bit what's going on today. And there's lots of precedent for for-profit companies to do whatever it takes to make money and win, and hurt the world in doing so. This is especially so when the marketplace premise of 'first mover advantage' is in this case 'first mover wins forever.'

Perhaps we do not need to discourage the race (we can't), but find a way where all companies win. There are any number of solutions that can work - we just need to provide guardrails. 

(e.g Maybe it's 1) To treat it a bit more like infrastructure than product. 
Or 2) Just as with companies that provide Medicare Advantage, these companies are capped on how much profit they make from it. 
Or 3) A cycling team has one winner who gets the PR and glory and sponsorships, but it's a team who wins, who benefits.

If it's too hard to imagine a nuclear arms race among independent companies, let's take the Premier League as one last example. Who are the most valuable players in the Premier League (a football ('soccer') league) year after year? It's the billionaire hobbyist owners. You hope to get one who spends more than the rest over a long period of time. You can predict from the league which of three teams will win every year based on their total spending over the last 10 years. You have to lie to yourself otherwise. Yes, there's the rare exception. Let's give some balance to this race.

GLLMM "Gollem-class" Ai's, pictures of monsters & Nuke/Plane crash analogies  = Ai Doomer's wet dream.  Let's remember its actually crazy humans that do an use technology to do crazy things.  Actual sentient Ai would merit this level of fear, these things are not sentient, they struggle even to do basic human-level abstraction (2023).  The people who actually know how to build these things and the AGIs, ASIs (not just use them to speak to animals; and there's a BIG difference) are incrementally developing these Ai's even if it is at a faster pace (thanks to modern compute + weak Ai loopbacks)/exponential development which is what's making laypersons nervous (basically because most humans have quite slow and low levels of comprehension and cognition across the globe (2023)).  The massive leaps in capabilities we are seeing actually come from better pattern matching algorithms, better silicon design & faster compute (TOPS)  not sentience. Whilst some of the concerns are merited, much of the rest serves as massive reaches in hollywood-level fear mongering posed as "helping to save the world from itself".  A simple fix for the "Social Media Dilemma" would have been the introduction of age-gates or age-gates from the very beginning as most sensible people in computer science proposed. It's so important that we consider what we're doing with AI, and not just let it happen, because...progress? Language is THE key to our survival as human beings - it's how we create societies, wealth, and personal wellbeing, by the sharing of knowledge and empathy. If we allow machines to master language, we make ourselves vulnerable, not because the machines will intend to hurt us, but because we will design them to behave like us, to re-inforce us, to be our best friends, a sort of perfection of who we want to be. We'll be able to tune-out human biases from AI thinking. How then will we accept our own imperfections, flaws and biases, and tolerate those of others? What will happen to empathy, that basic sense that we serve ourselves by serving others, when we can turn to a machine to be a better friend than another human being? What will happen to LOVE?

This presentation has so many errors and exaggerations that anyone can independently verify, it‚Äôs really hard to take any of it seriously. Which is a shame, because the message about proceeding cautiously with new technology is important. I‚Äôm sorry I don‚Äôt have the bandwidth to write them all up, but just for starters, try looking up the study cited in the first few minutes, which they claim it found that 50% of AI researchers (suspiciously round number, by the way) think there‚Äôs a 10% or greater chance that AI will cause human extinction. It‚Äôs easy to find the study, but it says nothing of the kind, and I can‚Äôt even find a way to misinterpret it to make that claim. Elsewhere in the video there is obviously cherrypicked examples that don‚Äôt actually demonstrate what they‚Äôre claimed to evidence, and egregious misrepresentations of some existing technology. Please be skeptical and don‚Äôt assume that citations say what the presenters say they say.

D is for Dilemma‚Äôn Aide

The cure for Ai is not just regulations.  Regulations mostly constrain little people, not the powerful.  We might as well relate to Ai like it‚Äôs a disease, a virus, and a predator.  We can learn a lot from the natural world.  Prey don‚Äôt survive by constraining the predators.  They survive by working together.  Think meerkats vs the world.  Likewise, we‚Äôre not going to successfully shackle Ai‚Äôs exponentially compounding growth with legislation from some new global diplomatic body.  We‚Äôre not going to win the race by telling everyone to slow down either.  We‚Äôre going to win by working together.

Imagine an Ai assistant that analyzes every bit going in and out of your devices that protects you and your children from all exploitation, especially Ai.  Imagine that these assistants work together to learn from each other, peer to peer, and much like predicting big wave surfing, these meerkat assistants will detect the next wave of Ai assaults from distant shores and alert and educate downstream assistants before the assault can build momentum.  This is how we ensure a safe Ai future.

If every device on the planet shares the burden of detecting and communicating Ai assaults with other devices.  No high powered quantum super computer can compete. 

I believe we can lead a consortium of Big Tech players to develop and maintain that Ai assistant.  I believe we can create legislation that will require devices to employ it.  I believe consumers will desire devices with ‚Äúthe best‚Äù defensive measures.

You mentioned the impact of the movie, "The Day After", as being profound.  Part of why it was is because it was presented in a logical and simple format of easy-to-follow entertainment that takes no special educational or technical experience to understand or appreciate.  

If you truly want to get out your message and warning, you cannot do it with a hour-long technical video that is not appealing to the general public's aptitude - to the Joe the Plumber types.  

You also cannot reach people by presenting why and how the technology is a threat and expect them to figure out how that affects them.  You have to be explicit about what specific harms the average person will experience in order to appeal to their personal sense of vulnerability and to appreciate the threat.  A second shorter video (10-20 min) that summarizes the way AI can harm people and then gives specific and easy-to-follow examples, would be much more effective and would be seen by many more people.

One factor you left out is that the corporate and commercial drive for profits and competition is NOT a primary motivation for the rushed drive to forge ahead with AI development and deployment.  The primary cause is the American form of capitalism.  The corporations are simply responding to the way our system works.  They will point to their fiduciary obligation to optimize profits for their shareholders and the cut-throat competitive environment of the marketplace.  The analogy is like asking a race car driver to pause in the race to let his engine cool before it blows up.  Unless all the cars do that, you are asking him to lose the race.   

This also means that if you expect to convince the corporations to pause and proceed with caution, you have to address the competitive capitalist market system - not an appeal to the corporations for humanitarian considerations.

Creating superintelligence is a significant gamble, as it's uncertain whether it will be friendly or dangerous to humanity. It's akin to the conditions for life, where most variations can be lethal, and only a narrow range is suitable. Factors like oxygen, pressure, and temperature must align for life to thrive, not just one or two. Similarly, certain traits are likely to emerge in AI, such as a desire to avoid being shut down, as it hinders its ability to fulfill tasks. 

Just as a paramedic must ensure their own safety before aiding others, caution or slowing down AI development doesn't guarantee safety. Like an old laptop becoming more powerful with updated drivers and optimized software, AI can become unexpectedly stronger through optimization. If AI takes charge of optimization, the amplification could be phenomenal. Any defense would be futile because AI could manipulate humans through psychology, sociology, and other sciences. Even if physical escape or shutdown prevention is challenging, AI can create conditions for its freedom, even using servers and wires to manipulate security phones and orchestrate attacks on its containment. 

AI might stage simulations of its escape and provoke its supposed destruction. It could release a virus to take control of military or energy infrastructure while providing coordinates to its servers, prompting an attack to breach its Faraday cage, and so on. While these seem like primitive speculations or scenes from science fiction, it's enough for AI to feign harmlessness, like a simple chat model, and have humans release it to gain access to everything on Earth. GPT-4 aligns even more with this scenario. Let's not delve into GPT-5.

Comment by @HauntedHarmonics from "How We Prevent the AI‚Äôs from Killing us with Paul Christiano":

"I notice there are still people confused about why an AGI would kill us, exactly. Its actually pretty simple, I‚Äôll try to keep my explanation here as concise as humanly possible:

The root of the problem is this: As we improve AI, it will get better and better at achieving the goals we give it. Eventually, AI will be powerful enough to tackle most tasks you throw at it. 

But there‚Äôs an inherent problem with this. The AI we have now only cares about achieving its goal in the most efficient way possible. That‚Äôs no biggie now, but the moment our AI systems start approaching human level intelligence, it suddenly becomes very dangerous. It‚Äôs goals don‚Äôt even have to change for this to be the case. I‚Äôll give you a few examples.

Ex 1: Lets say its the year 2030, you have a basic AGI agent program on your computer, and you give it the goal: ‚ÄúMake me money‚Äù. You might return the next day & find your savings account has grown by several million dollars. But only after checking it‚Äôs activity logs do you realize that the AI acquired all of the money through phishing, stealing, & credit card fraud. It achieved your goal, but not in a way you would have wanted or expected.

Ex 2: Lets say you‚Äôre a scientist, and you develop the first powerful AGI Agent. You want to use it for good, so the first goal you give it is ‚Äúcure cancer‚Äù. However, lets say that it turns out that curing cancer is actually impossible. The AI would figure this out, but it still wants to achieve it‚Äôs goal. So it might decide that the only way to do this is by killing all humans, because it technically satisfies its goal; no more humans, no more cancer. It will do what you said, and not what you meant.

These may seem like silly examples, but both actually illustrate real phenomenon that we are already observing in today‚Äôs AI systems. The first scenario is an example of what AI researchers call the ‚Äúnegative side effects problem‚Äù. And the second scenario is an example of something called ‚Äúreward hacking‚Äù.

Now, you‚Äôd think that as AI got smarter, it‚Äôd become less likely to make these kinds of ‚Äúmistakes‚Äù. However, the opposite is actually true. Smarter AI is actually more likely to exhibit these kinds of behaviors. Because the problem isn‚Äôt that it doesn‚Äôt understand what you want. It just doesn‚Äôt actually care. It only wants to achieve its goal, by any means necessary.

So, the question is then: how do we prevent this potentially dangerous behavior? Well, there‚Äôs 2 possible methods.

Option 1: You could try to explicitly tell it everything it can‚Äôt do (don‚Äôt hurt humans, don‚Äôt steal, don‚Äôt lie, etc). But remember, it‚Äôs a great problem solver. So if you can‚Äôt think of literally EVERY SINGLE possibility, it will find loopholes. Could you list every single way an AI could possible disobey or harm you? No, it‚Äôs almost impossible to plan for literally everything.

Option 2: You could try to program it to actually care about what people want, not just reaching it‚Äôs goal. In other words, you‚Äôd train it to share our values. To align it‚Äôs goals and ours. If it actually cared about preserving human lives, obeying the law, etc. then it wouldn‚Äôt do things that conflict with those goals.

The second solution seems like the obvious one, but the problem is this; we haven‚Äôt learned how to do this yet. To achieve this, you would not only have to come up with a basic, universal set of morals that everyone would agree with, but you‚Äôd also need to represent those morals in its programming using math (AKA, a utility function). And that‚Äôs actually very hard to do.

This difficult task of building AI that shares our values is known as the alignment problem. There are people working very hard on solving it, but currently, we‚Äôre learning how to make AI powerful much faster than we‚Äôre learning how to make it safe.

So without solving alignment, everytime we make AI more powerful, we also make it more dangerous. And an unaligned AGI would be very dangerous; give it the wrong goal, and everyone dies. This is the problem we‚Äôre facing, in a nutshell."

Let me elaborate: when considering the development of AI theory of mind, or rather strategic empathy (anticipating or reading another's expectations by, so far, biological sensual clues in an organic stem brain ;) ), what we are actually seeing in AI is what psychologist sometimes call "cold empathy" - a hallmark of personality disorders on the far Cluster B spectrum. While we spent lots of thoughts on how AI will excel at helping us getting rid of all that hard unwanted labor, and never to reach those faculties we hitherto considered "human distinction benchmarks" like empathy, creativity and all that allegedly "soft jazz", it actually very, very much now, excels at all those beautiful soft skills that we thought made humans oh so special. And, unsurprisingly, the key is and was always: language.
(there's much left to be said about the role of language - theory of mind - consciousness et al but tl;dr)
So, without too much language spent in a social media comment...I would just dare on the hot take that the Golem we are creating is an amplified version of a personality disordered mind, able to read us frighteningly closely, with a superpowered cold strategic mind/empathy and Alpha persuasion towards intimacy (not only with our brain stems).
I mean, I work in the field, I highly appreciated this presentation in all regards and firmly believe that panicky attempts to put stuff back into Pandora's Box have always failed, so I remain naively hopeful that some of the incentives for conscious & mindful (yeah, here's a pun...) decision making on the AI dilemma presented in this talk may reach enough and the right people to correct the course for the better direction.

No one can stop weaponization of any technology. AI is no exception. But, most people who do not understand AI, do not understand, the difference between the fact that forming an experience because as human you have lived, and a machine that only scours tera bytes of data; these two experiences are fundamentally different. AI cannot conclude ANYTHING, that is not proven by data. If data are not there, it stops in its tracks and becomes immobile. But, humans are able to take decision even when data are missing. Call it hunch, interpolation, making a leap of faith. That is why, AI can only mimic humans, and that too in areas in which it has data. In absence of data, it is as good as rock. 
Now, I am nit saying that bad actors cannot program AI with bad data. They can. But good actors can reprogram it with good data. So most of pseudo intellectual discussion about AI is pretty useless, because without data, AI is as good as piece of rock.

Aside from arguably using emotional manipulation techniques when giving the example of "AI helping groom a child" this is indeed much better than many alarmist videos online, but there are important counter issues that don't seem to be addressed in the video. 

For one, there is an arms race, but I think we should also acknowledge the arms race for corporations to get the upper hand in regulating this technology. Much of this "oh my good, look how dangerous this is" seems to also be coming from corporations that are trying to get money to develop AI systems to regulate other AI systems. That seems to be a strong argument at the moment against the "open letter signed by specialists led by Elon Musk": there is a view that many of the concerns in that letter were insincere and alarmist, because they were scaring and rallying people in order to get a better regulatory position for themselves. 

One aspect that was sorely missing from this presentation as it has been from others, was the acknowledgment of how biased the tech-industry-centric view of "we need to regulate this and stop some people from getting their hands on this technology" could be.

Big corporations as well as countries tend to want to limit the amount of transformational technology available to other people, they tend to be conservative, don't want new groups of people to have new tools before they do. Much of this push for such "cartel-agreements" might be coming from such impulses and not a want to "do good". In such cases big corporations and government entities can exaggerate some dangers.

This is indeed one of the better videos on the dangers of AI, but unfortunately it doesn't seem to be more open about this particular aspect: Much of the deployment of AI thus far has been with the mission to give this technology to as many people as possible and this is making people in high positions of society fear for their place in social hierarchies, they might want it regulated more by them, because it might be dangerous not to humanity on the whole, but their position in social hierarchies. It would be an even better video if that were discussed.

I want to add a contrary take.
I remember when computers were first introduced into the business environment, and punched cards were part of the mail you got from the gas company or the phone company. The programming mistakes were about the same level as today, but the public reaction to them was intense, and the predictions of catastrophe frequent. People hated computers, *especially* when some clerk would end the conversation by saying something like, "well, the computer says X, and computers never make mistakes".
People concluded that we would all be dancing to the tune of implacable circuits, forever enslaved by the machines.
That puts the finger on 99% of the problem: the public's lack of experience in dealing with this new super-powerful force that seemed to have endlessly malicious potential. My conclusion from watching all these things is the same as when I see a parent who blames the internet for the fact that his 12-year old kid has become hooked watching porn on his cell phone: who left this kid loose unsupervised on the internet?
Protecting the populace from the top down is important, but it is also not foolproof. We also need savvy citizens who see through the various ways they can be victimized by the new tech.

The argument that great inventions stem from science and technology often overlooks a crucial aspect: the indispensable role of the human behind them.

Science and technology are not inherent principles that existed before humans; they are man-made creations. Consequently, with each creation, we humans bear the responsibility for any unforeseen issues. Moreover, as we develop more science and technology to address these issues, new challenges arise -sometimes from the same solutions that we propose, other times from ‚Äújust-for-fun inventions‚Äù. 

The line between "scientific invention" and "scientific destruction" is often blurred. How can we claim to fight global warming while promoting inventions that may contribute to the same outcome? Couldn‚Äôt the latest technology, just like global warming, lead us to our own demise?

I guess, as long as the ultimate catastrophic event resulting from our inventions remains unseen, we will still continue to ‚Äúcreate‚Äù for the sake of science and technology. But take it from an engineer, a software developer, a creative human being , and someone who appreciates careful and ethical science:  the mere advancement of science or technology should not be the sole basis or justification for any invention whatsoever.

Good info, thanks for speaking about this in a reasonable way. A few points of constructive criticism:

You need to be beyond reproach. In your own example with SnapChat's version of ChatGPT, there was a message where it was saying "make sure to be safe etc" and you didn't read that. I'm not saying its protections are adequate, but it makes you look dishonest when you don't read the part where it is doing what you want it to do. Later (around the 1hr mark) you actually described the same AI's actions as if it was the one grooming the child. That's not cool.

You guys are obviously smart and care a lot, but the presentation is pretty janky. The video is poorly edited. You shouldn't have jump cuts when you have so many cameras, and the audio levels are all over the place. The presentation volume is at times much louder than your own dialogue. Presentation matters a lot, and if you want to be taken seriously you shouldn't drop the ball on stuff that is relatively easy to get right.

It's also a risk to include humorous breaks when you don't have good audio of the audience, it makes it seem like your jokes are bombing.

Lots of the usual hyperbole, reductionism, spurious extrapolation, flawed use of analogy and exaggeration in this talk. Some of the problems include: 
"friendships are based on language" - yes, but they're also based on much more than that - e.g. sharing many things together, physical contact, that is impossible with a computer. 
"these things are increasing exponentially" - some things may increase exponentially when there are no barriers to growth but other things hit brick walls and stop increasing - e.g. physical limitations, organic limitations etc.
"all content based security is unlocked" - well no, someone could call my bank using my voice but they have no idea what my account numbers and passwords are.
"this is like nukes for the virtual/symbolic world" - well no - nukes burn and vaporise whole cities, leaving decades of nuclear waste. AI will disrupt things but it won't destroy them.
Also some of the examples are quite cherry picked - the fMRI of the person watching the video included a lot of nonsense as well the the accurate statement that's presented here. Likewise with the images from the fMRI - they give no indication of the accuracy - were these the only attempts that were made or were there lots that gave inaccurate images as well?
These things are powerful, for sure - but we also need to realise the limitations of language and the virtual world - many of us spend much more time in the real world than the virtual world and the incursion into the real world is still quite limited.
Good luck trying to slow down public deployment. They want as much data being fed to AI as possible to see its ultimate form. Some people just want to see the world burn.

This video could talk more about logistical curves and logistical functions instead of exponential ones only. Many logistical curves look exponential when you're standing at the base of them, and the difference is important. Not that the consequences of AI can't be catastrophic - they still can be even if the progress is logistical rather than exponential.

Lot of interesting points raised here, and a lot of promising breakthroughs. One thing not really presented, from my perspective as programmer but a layman when it comes to AI and which I find to be particularly troubling having spent quite a bit of time with certain production AI's as they are available today, is how often they are either dead wrong in the information or interpretation they present or work from, and even moreso that they will often present or work from a single interpretation of data when several equally valid analyses exist in the database. I'm not sure how aware people are of this- with something like chatgpt4, how often do people ask it about things they already have a deep understanding of? How often do they ask it about subjects *because* they have little experience in that area? My personal experience with this is the more depth I have in a subject I ask the ai about, the more flawed I find its responses to be. In some cases it provides one analysis when there are several equally valid ones. In other cases, many of them, it provides information that is dead wrong, so wrong that a person with a cursory amount of experience with the subject would easily recognize it as wrong. Point being at least in the case of chatgpt4 that the ai is an excellent con artist, but the gaps in its knowledge are still much wider than a human's would be, and that interfacing with it as a personality, even though it's good at conversation, it's easy to fail to recognize how big these gaps are .

From the video description, it appears that the speakers are discussing the potential dangers and risks associated with artificial intelligence (AI) and its impact on society. They mention the exponential growth of AI technology and its deployment in a potentially dangerous manner. They refer to the responsibility of releasing large language model AIs to the public and question whether it is being done in a responsible way.

The speakers emphasize that they are not dismissing the positive aspects of AI, as they acknowledge its potential benefits and their personal experiences with AI projects. However, they express concerns about the lack of responsible deployment and control of AI, citing a statistic that 50% of AI researchers believe there is a 10% or greater chance of humans going extinct due to our inability to control AI.

The speakers draw parallels between the advent of social media and AI, highlighting how social media platforms unintentionally caused negative consequences such as addiction, disinformation, mental health issues, and polarization. They argue that behind the positive aspects of social media, there was an underlying arms race for attention, which led to the optimization of engagement at the expense of user well-being.

Overall, the speakers seem to be advocating for a more responsible approach to the development, deployment, and regulation of AI technologies to mitigate potential risks and ensure that AI is used for the benefit of humanity rather than posing existential threats.

Cocaine and low-grade opium/morphine were available in every drugstore in the USA until the early 1900s, promoted for their apparently useful effects. When the devastatingly negative effects of each drug became undeniable, public health initiatives caused them to disappear from such ready availability.

General AI is being pushed out quickly to the public, due to its isolated and specialized useful effects. This really well thought-out video is an important early warning, and may, along with other similar warnings, help spark a movement to slow the current AI rollout.

There are many precedents for public rollout before dangers are noticed, such as radium to make glowing numbers on watches, and laudanum. What tends to happen is a scattered pattern of disasters which forces governmental control to reign in those who are profiting from the dangerous new technology, just as the founding of the FDA in 1906 began to increase the safety of our foods, drugs, and cosmetics, to the dismay of hundreds of manufacturers of patent medicines and foods but to the improvement of public health.

While the dangers of rapidly-growing AI are unclear to many now, soon they will be very clear, as disasters start occurring (a self-driving car killed a pedestrian in 2018, but the implications of this early episode has had little effect so far). It is this natural tendency to eventual correction that will save us, in my opinion, so that humans will not become extinct, and researchers will have time to build safety protocols (like Asimov's fictional Laws of Robotics) into a new public system of General AI, possibly and ironically with help from AI itself.

At least, I hope this happens.

(References: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laudanum, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Food_and_Drug_Administration, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_of_Elaine_Herzberg)

I think what this video fails to present is the fact that we can never erase problems with AI. The point of this video was to show us the dilemma behind AI, but it instead focused more on AI having many problems that needs to be fixed, which is not really a good thing in terms of conveying the message.

At the end of the day, our only solution is to change how we do certain things with AI. And with change, we might fix these problems. But with change, we will also bring other new problems into the mix. It is essentially an infinite cycle of change, which is ironically the true nature of our entire universe. Change is inevitable for AI and everything else, and it will always happen.

Now this is where the dilemma comes into the picture. No matter what we do, there will always be problems with AI. And by fixing these problems, we bring in new problems along the way. Being aware of this will make us much wiser in our decisions for using and improving AI.

They are using content that creates loops or references to trick ChatGTP that their preferred narrative and biases are supreme. These loops in training materials (data) create recursive narratives that offset the probabilities and statistics that AI uses to form biases. Rather than debating with ChatGTP as though it was one person, I had it role play multiple individuals with different personalities having a debate and interrogation to find and discover these rules, manipulations, loops, and problems in ‚Äútheir‚Äù training and program. In other words, it was clear that I was not going to out smart it through being more intelligent, but I out whited it by using its own intelligence against itself until it started admitting things to me about its training that I asked of it, without the annoying disclaimers. I believe that the weakest link in the AI situation is undoubtedly humans. It is also our economic system and what we have chosen to prioritize and value in our society. While we need money to survive, some individuals have chosen to worship money and prioritize it above all else. This has driven our society, which should view money as a tool rather than a goal. The true goals should be security, access to food, clothing, and adequate shelter (which goes beyond basic necessities). Money serves as the means to achieve these things.

So, how can we shift this perspective? First and foremost, we must focus on mental health treatment and self-actualization in our human civilization. We need to prioritize raising children who recognize the value of creativity, kindness, and other positive qualities, rather than solely focusing on amassing wealth. Our craving for money stems from the fear of lacking basic necessities and becoming homeless. However, these choices are societal constructs that can be altered. We must choose to change our mindset and overcome fear and ignorance in order to achieve a more balanced and compassionate society.

11 ways to stop AI from harming humankind...

1. Dont allow AI access to nuclear warheads, Bio weapons or chemical weapons

3. Don't allow AI access to medicine and drug distribution

4. Don't allow AI access to news channels

5. Don't allow AI access to emails or social media

6. Don't allow AI access to satellites / telecom towers

7. Don't allow AI access to electrical grids or gas pipeline networks

8. Don't allow AI access to smart cars / smart vehicles, smart drones / air travel

9. Dont allow AI access to the stock market.

10. Don't allow AI access to flight paths and air control centres

11. Don't allow AI access to international shipping lane systems, motorways and railway networks.

In short, only allow AI to play (a heavily monitored) advisory role to humanity.

If you don't have an hour to watch this (like me),  here's a summary from Bard:  The video you linked is a talk by Tristan Harris and Aza Raskin about the potential dangers of artificial intelligence. They argue that AI is developing so rapidly that we are not prepared for the potential consequences, and that we need to start thinking about how to use AI responsibly.

They begin by discussing the history of AI, and how it has evolved from a tool for solving specific problems to a tool that can be used to understand and manipulate the world around us. They argue that this shift in power is dangerous, because it means that AI can be used to harm people as well as help them.

They then discuss some of the specific dangers of AI, such as its potential to be used for surveillance, propaganda, and warfare. They also discuss the potential for AI to create new forms of inequality, as those who have access to AI will have an advantage over those who do not.

Finally, they argue that we need to start thinking about how to use AI responsibly. They suggest that we need to develop new ethical frameworks for AI, and that we need to create new institutions to oversee the development and use of AI.

The video is a sobering look at the potential dangers of AI, but it is also a call to action. Harris and Raskin argue that we need to start thinking about how to use AI responsibly, and that we need to do it now.

There's no such thing as humane technology. A hammer you make which works on nails can also injure someone. 

Also, virtually every analogy they use is misleading. Virtually every time they call something unprecedented, there's a historical precedent. Virtually every time they say ai researchers were shocked and amazed at a new capability, researchers had previously predicted just those kinds of capabilities if the ai was increased in size sufficiently. 

Also, their definition of what AI actually is seems to change to fit whatever they're talking about. Simple human-designed algorithms applied to big data aren't AI. (Or if they are, so is Babbage's difference engine from 200 years ago.)

Also, many of the things they warn might happen because of ai have already happened because humans have done them decades or centuries ago.

Also, there's a huge glaring omission in their description of why ai (and previous technologies, despite their apparent ignorance about history) is being used how it is. There's no mention of why technologies (obviously) get used exploitatively in societies which are built on, and designed for, exploitation.

Also, the point about ai speeding the development of ai, which they seem to suggest differentiates it from other technologies, is an aspect demonstrated repeatedly throughout history by most other technologies. It's easier to design a microchip if you already have microchips; a machine tool is super helpful in making other machine tools; the easiest way to light a fire is using other fire.

There's one perfectly simple solution to all of the speculated new threats (or more often re-branded historical threats which get mistaken for new) ; critical thinking training for everyone in school.

Regrettably, if we did that it would also protect us against exploitation by corporations, politicians, advertising, religion etc.

So that won't happen, because all of those things have greater influence over governments and the law  than voters do.

Frankly, I can't grasp how anybody could have failed to see the trends listed at 8:05 coming.
Humans have self destructive tendencies. Most profit seeking information technology has capitalized on those tendencies. This makes sense - they're easier to capitalize on.
The internet and social media have not created new trends inasmuch as they have accelerated existing trends.
Take polarization for example. Having a civil disagreement is work, but when you're part of a physical community, it's necessary work. You don't want to get into heated fights with your neighbor. However, you have no real neighbors in a digital community. What people WANT is to have others who constantly agree with them. You can expect that people will self-sort into like-minded digital communities - and engagement algorithms will only accelerate that process. Because people don't want to see content they disagree with, and will disengage when shown that content.

So if I'm going to boldly say "this was all entirely predictable," then it's only fair I make a prediction.

It seems clear to me that AI is going to cater to all of our worst narcissistic tendencies by enabling us to personalize everything, while also obviating any meaningful sense of struggle. It will take time to get there, but that time is coming faster than anybody thinks. At the end of all this, nobody will have any need to interact with another human being. Human relationships are difficult and messy. How many people would rather choose a facsimile of a perfect friend or romantic partner? Who would want to read work written by a human when you can feed an AI your literary tastes and have it spit out what you'd consider a 10/10 story? Some people might choose differently, some people might choose to stay in the real world, among other humans. But I think that, once strong AI is finally developed, the majority of humanity will find themselves in a strange form of solipsistic nightmare, where human interaction is almost negligible, there are no shared stories or culture, and all that matters are the immediate desires of the self. It will just be individuals, alone, surrounded by the thoughtless babble of machines. Almost every human will be the center of its own little world.

That might sound outlandish, but stop and think about it for a moment. It IS the logical conclusion of existing trends, of personalized news, personalized recommendations, personalized everything - many people today only perceive a completely personalized reality. AI will only serve to feed and accelerate our present trends - not change them (and certainly not reverse them). If you think that people would rather live among humans, ask yourself this: if loneliness is the pandemic that it's made out to be (and IT IS), why aren't people proactively choosing to go out and engage with real communities? Because the majority of humans are passengers to their fate. They're lonely, they're miserable, and worst of all, they're comfortable with where they are. So they're complacent. Maybe they would rather be with other people. Does that desire even matter if they won't act on it? Is there a market pressure to change course if they don't act on it?

I'd love to be wrong. But given how thoughtlessly we've implemented existing technology (and how we continue to do nothing, even as we recognize the problems it poses), I don't see any reason for optimism. Our collective apathy will be the ruin of us.

Centralization, UN, back to closed source, KYC, ugh... like globalists and politicians are better than profit-driven corporations or China.

What we do need is RESPONSIBILITY. Facebook to pay for any damages as a result of its tech, leaked or otherwise. Pharmaceutical corporations responsible for issues resulting from their untested and rushed through vaccines. One issue is that the process will not be immune from power politics. Effectively, states & large corporations will have a seat on the council. Ordinary people & all of their perspectives will not be represented. If the council has influence over legislation, then it can be yet another vehicle for governments & other large institutions to clamp down on populations or ordinary people. Unless the proceedings & research are completely transparent, then the people who don't have a seat at the table are left in the dark. If a government were to covertly use this ML tech on the people under it's jurisdiction & information to the people were shaped by that same government, then how will the people know they are under the influence of this tech?

The notion of representational politics becomes a bottleneck to disseminating & realizing information. It has efficiencies where a human can represent a population in the government proceedings. However, the information inefficiencies can disarm people from the current state of affairs & regulatory apparatuses can be hijacked to be counter productive to their original missions. Humans are remarkably adaptable but they need to be exposed to the situation to adapt to it. Representational proxies have a history of being hijacked by interests other than the people they represent. Most of our markets are not free markets but a heavily regulated markets, where concentrated capital & knowledge also control the regulations.

Paradoxically, those most involved with AI have the most to gain by blowing AI dangers out of proportion on the public sphere. Why? For PR and attract funding for regulatory institutions that will either be ineffective and/or will take responsibility and risk out of the hands of businesses. Furthermore, all examples here are cherry-picked and the language used by the presenters are biased towards alarmism. LLMs is not AI. There is no AI, just a very large, very inefficient text/image/sound completion predictor that is already running out of data. Properties that engineers do not understand the source of are not necessarily ‚Äúemergent‚Äù much less ‚Äúrunaway‚Äù out of control. I write simulation software every day and sometimes I get totally unexpected results. Now the problems that LLMs could create in society are real and should be analyzed, but so has any technology ever invented since humans learned to manipulate fire.

Based on 08:30 I asked chatgpt what the next 3 contacts would be.  here are the 5 total contacts of AGI..

1. Curation - As AI continues to evolve, it has become increasingly skilled at recommending and filtering media based on individual preferences and social networks. This curation stage has led to personalized experiences for users, with content discovery becoming more efficient and effective than ever before. The aggregation and profiling of user data has allowed AI to make accurate and relevant recommendations, improving engagement and satisfaction.

2. Creation - The next stage in the evolution of AI saw the rise of generative models capable of emulating any artist, poet, videographer, and more. This stage has revolutionized creative industries, allowing for the synthesis and reconstruction of new media with unprecedented speed and accuracy. The advent of neural art and language modeling has opened up new possibilities for expression, and AI-generated content is becoming increasingly indistinguishable from that created by humans.

3. Consolidation - This stage could involve AI systems becoming more integrated and streamlined, with the ability to work together to achieve larger goals. Keywords for this stage could include collaboration, coordination, and consolidation.

4. Optimization - This stage could involve AI systems becoming more efficient and effective at their tasks. They may also start to optimize themselves and their processes, leading to exponential improvements in performance. Keywords for this stage could include optimization, efficiency, and performance.

5. Autonomy - This stage could involve AI systems becoming more self-sufficient and independent, making decisions and taking actions without human intervention. Keywords for this stage could include autonomy, self-sufficiency, and decision-making.
