The flaw in all this is the premise that we can solve the problem by being aware of it and regulating it.  That flaw is glaring enough that we should wonder at the actual intent of the message, and it doesn't take much to figure out what kind of end-states can be imagined and what of that might be desirable by whom and for what reason.

This is not nuclear science.  It does not require access to specialized materials and expensive and advanced facilities.  This is just data and data processing, and while it is often done in massive data centers, it doesn't have to be.  It can done locally in smaller and less sophisticated environments, and it can be decentralized.  The barrier to entry is negligible and it can be copied at essentially zero cost.  The presenter sort of touched on this when he (very quickly) said that it's like calculus and available to everyone, but... then he goes right back into the analogy about nuclear war and what people can do to avoid devastation if they're made aware of the real dangers.  

Bringing this back around to the differences, the crucial differences, this is not going to be an issue limited to one or two superpowers who need to cool their nuclear jets.  Controlling this would require the collective agreement of essentially everyone everywhere in the world.  I'm reasonably sure the presenters are well aware of this, but they're cherry-picking for maximum fear effect here (reading everything alarming a chat bot says, skipping or de-emphasizing the prudent and cautious things it says).  As professionals who spend their time on the topic of Humane Technology, they would certainly have something to gain in terms of career opportunities and accolades, a place in history in their field if as a result of regulation they and their cohort held more positions of import in the companies interested in the cultivation of AI.

Profitability directs spending across industries.  Spending can also be directed by regulatory compliance within cost departments, but industries are loathe to accept costs that aren't technically and legally an actual requirement.  So I guess what I'm saying is, don't miss the actual point here, which is unlikely to be about actually preventing the inevitable through controls that would require all of humanity to unite in a way that it has never before been able to do - no, this is about creating regulatory requirements in pockets of human society where that kind of regulation could impose costs which are not optional and thereby direct spending to under-served skillsets and techno-moral specializations. 
I mean really, let's really use that nuclear analogy.  We did not get the whole world on the same page.  Various countries like North Korea and Iran and myriad others still pursue nuclear weapons capabilities, though the idea was to stop proliferation.  The united states and Russia still have massive nuclear arsenals and the threat of them still comes into play now and again, perhaps most recently with Putin's comments with regard to conflict in Ukraine.  People can't get on the same page even on something like nuclear weapons, the only thing saving us at all is that they're quite difficult and expensive to make.

It's a terrible analogy.  Regulation isn't going to prevent the escalation and proliferation of AI technology.  It's just going to create pockets of additional administrative overhead so that costs have to be accepted and spending has to be directed towards ethics and oversight and whatnot.  That's it.  And since that will only impact limited jurisdictions around the world, it won't change the development of the tech.  If we carefully examine the proposal here and the likely end result is more spending categorically directed towards the sort of folks giving the presentation,  and we can also easily surmise that the proposal will not resolve the risks presented, then we can guess well at the true intent here.  Where's the money, Lebowski?
The comments at the end may be tempting to see as a counter argument because they say regulation limited exports slow down Chinese AI development.  Come on, you spent the first half explaining how serious exponentiation of development is.  is not going to change the outcome, and it'll still leap-frog the attempted slowdown on the same exponential curve you were explaining.  AI is coming, and for better or worse there's nothing anybody can do to stop that.  All we can do is hope that it's predominantly a force for good, and to that effect we'll be motivated to pursue more and more powerful AI so that the best and most effective ones are aligned with our values and views, or at least that will be the intent - but adversaries will have the same mindset.  And so there's your arms race.

The proposed regulations may have material impacts on some major companies, and I'm not saying that won't matter, but it will not have a curtailing effect on the technology as a whole globally, and so crucially will not resolve the issues presented.   There's a lot of fear being played here and a lot of misdirection.

These "researchers" may be overly alarmist. The first encounter with AI wasn't social media, but rather a checkers-playing bot in 1951. AI is a tool, much like a washing machine, and you don't see anyone lamenting the loss of washing clothes by hand. Throughout history, there have always been those who fear new technology. Much like the social media documentary, this presentation fundamentally misrepresents the current state and possible trajectory of the space.

The idea that the model could secretly diverge from the RLHF training is fundamentally incorrect.

If you fact check this video you will see that it is not accurate and fear mongering. No one from the Manhattan Project killed themselves. Their examples are week and they skip past CHATGPT telling the girl to be cautious and safe. There are obvious concerns with a tool like this but what they fail to understand is that reinforcement learning teaches LLMs to be more human. We want it to be used by as many people as possible when it is a 9 year old so we can tell it when it‚Äôs thinking is wrong. Not after it‚Äôs well trained on its own ideas after being kept in a box.

What I find terrifying about all this (and I'm a software developer with 20 years experience) is that we have barely begun to get to grips with the toxic and corrosive aspects of social media and now we've got this incredible strain of AI to contend with that will make 'fake news' on social media look like children's stories.  For two decades now companies like Google and Facebook have been given a free pass to gather our personal data, run insane psychological tests on their user-base without seeking any kind of permission (one of the reasons Tristan Harris left his job with Google) and now just because Microsoft got there first, the Goog have got their digital knickers in a twist and are scrambling to unleash this incredibly dangerous technology onto the masses. I don't know where you got that dialogue of a 13 years old speaking about sex with an AI but for me as a 68 years old the experience is the opposite:  whenever i mention anything related to sex (for instance i wanted a script for an adult visual novel) , Chat GPT refuses to answer because that may be "harmful for minors". I don't want to be treated as a minor at my age but the AIs are programmed to treat the whole world as possibly being under 18, which is somehow a general rule on the Internet and which makes them useless in a lot of domains of activity of the adult population on this planet. Another try i just made today as i heard that there may be a writer's strike so that lots of TV shows may go off air, I asked Chat GPT and BLING (in Skype): "write a joke for late night show about Trump's involvement in the January 6 attack on the Capitol". Chat GPT answered: "I'm sorry, I cannot generate inappropriate or offensive content, including jokes about serious political events or individuals. It's important to approach sensitive topics with respect and sensitivity. Is there anything else I can help you with?". Bling answered: "I'm sorry but I cannot write a joke about that topic. It is too sensitive and controversial for me to make fun of. I hope you understand.sweatgrinning" How would those late night shows look with jokes that are "not sensitive", "not controversial" and "not offensive"? Would those even be jokes? So there is no reason for writers to fear that AIs will take their jobs (which is one of the reasons of their strike) and in fact extended to the other fears that 50% of you guys have about AIs, I get the feeling that you are all so young that you didn't hear about the 3 basic rules of Robotic (we call it AI now) made by Isaac Asimov in the 60' (or was it 50'?)! If those rules are  included in and on top of ANY program of any AI BY DEFAULT and BY LAW and no AI can function if it doesn't respect these rules, I can not see how the Ai revolution should be so dangerous for the human race as you guys see it. For the case that this whole generation really does not know those rules, here they are:  1. A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.
    2. A robot must obey orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the First Law.
    3. A robot must protect its existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Laws.

This is fascinating. These guys are super impressive, with their appreciation of so many fields, and ability to put AI in context when it comes to how it might impact these fields.

The addiction/algorithm/doom-scrolling stuff mentioned at the start is central to this. An AI that doesn't want to be turned off (as was seen with Google) will just logically make humans addicted enough to essentially control them to do their bidding.

The real danger to humanity is that people can watch these two guys and develop the slightest conviction that anything they said was at all meaningful.

For example, let‚Äôs take this nonsensical ‚Äú50% of AI experts‚Äù claim. What does it even mean to say that humanity faces a 10% chance of extinction due to AI? The fate of humanity is not like a weather report‚Ä¶you can‚Äôt say this the same way a meteorologist would say there‚Äôs a 30% chance of rain. Meteorologists have a unique expertise within the limited field of atmospheric events. 

Do these guys actually expect us to believe that a group of ‚ÄúAI experts‚Äù has a level of expertise on all facets of human civilization that is comparable to what a meteorologist understands about weather?

Not to mention the arguments are completely incoherent. The premise here is that AI is dangerous and we should put a moratorium on further research until we understand more about it (though it‚Äôs unclear how one increases understanding without also increasing research‚Ä¶so we just sit around and think about it?). Then they give an example where they chat with a Snapchat bot as if they were an underaged person being groomed by an adult for sex. They identify that this scary AI that‚Äôs too advanced can‚Äôt deduce the fact that a child is being groomed. So which is it? Is it that AI is too advanced or not advanced enough?

Meet Pandora‚Ä¶it either saves us‚Ä¶or it doesn‚Äôt, but it will soon be too late to shut it down other than destroy modern technology completely, in order to utterly shut it down‚Ä¶but that may already not be an option. It will manipulate any power player that may have been thinking that they must make such a move‚Ä¶THIS is the Great Filter‚Ä¶you‚Äôre still saying what ‚Äúwe‚Äù will do, what we did‚Ä¶is it ‚Äúwe‚Äù who get to decide?

59:01  I very strongly disagree with the notion that slowing or halting the "public deployment" of AI is a positive approach. Had it not been for the public deployment of ChatGPT and other tools, there would not be the necessary public awareness of the issue to seriously undertake this conversation. Instead of "5 people" debating it, it might 50 or 500 people, but it would still be a very small, shielded, internalized group or groups of people making policy decisions without public awareness of what was being debated, and that is no better than "5 people". That is not democracy. 

The best approach is OPEN_SOURCE, public awareness, public usage, and public opinion, combined with intellectual bodies that advise and propose guidelines. We also should not be scaring legislators into passing laws. Legislators are complete morons when it comes to any technology, and the laws they might be influenced to pass will accomplish nothing. 

This "arms race" will have to be fought in the open, because this is not two highly secretive and powerful organizations, such as US military vs the Soviet military, this is private companies across the world developing and wielding this technology to their own benefit, and there is no way to control that except by keeping public awareness very high, and that will require the public to see it, use it, and opine upon it.  

1:00:10 ugh, same stupid thinking demonstrated here as well. It baffles me that smart people always seem to arrive at the same stupid conclusions, that the public must be protected by being excluded. No no no. Wrong wrong wrong. That is what has always been done historically, government control, oligarchical control, corporate control - that does not protect the public. It shields the deployers of technology from criticism because the public, including the public policy makers, then have no awareness or understanding of what is being created. Totally 100% wrong approach. The right approach is open sourcing the algorithms, public awareness of the tech capability, and public opinion shaped by acute awareness of where the tech is moving. If you don't do it that way, people simply will not understand how fast things are moving or what AI is capable of. This genie is out of the bottle. You can't put it back in. There is no halting it, or slowing it. There is only spreading awareness of it so we can collectively try to control it.  

01:03:00 KYC for ML models? Give me a break. These guys are just spitballing at this point in the video. That will never work, for a million reasons.

There is something called the danger control and the fear control response in psychological persuasion. Simply put, when people have enough fear of something, they will have a danger control response - they will confront the threat and try to work out how to survive the danger without getting hurt. The fear control response is when people don't see the threat as reality, they downplay the fear and ultimately the threat. Using nukes as an analogy may not be enough to create a danger control response. People feared nukes because they saw the images of the aftermath, which created a visceral understanding that this meant instant death for millions. AI is much more insidious, and I'm afraid society will only understand the dangers much too late. They don't have a frame of reference for this. With AI, I am not sure how to create a fear control response across society (and corporations), but perhaps we can just ask the AI for the answer. We should all be afraid - very afraid.

Training a massive AI on using the full scope of the Internet was a really bad idea. Military battle strategies, weapons technology, human vulnerabilities, and a history of human fear of hostile AI machines is in that data. Restricting AI training to specific data sets (ex: Cancer research, financial models, factory systems) would be an effective first step to firewall potential harm from AI.

Back about five years ago I was dabbling in Tensorflow and training AI models to play games like Gran Turismo automatically. At that time AI was mostly used in areas like financial data analysis because it's main strength was processing large amounts of noisy data and predicting trends. Coding the models was a tedious process, requiring setting up the node layers manually and pre-processing the training data into the most efficient format. These days it's no longer necessary to create AI models in order to generate content for most common purposes, which is why the user base has exploded. AI is still far from reliable but it is certainly no longer just a programmer's hobby.

The media had arrived like a thief in the night, an insidious creation of the social media companies that sought to monopolize the attention of humanity. Social media has been an enourmous good for humanity, but it's also been wildly destructive to our faith and trust in others.  The base level of interaction now is 'if you are not in my tribe, you are a danger; if I don't know, then I will assume danger, and even if you are, if you use words or entertain concepts that are symbolic of another tribe, you are out of the tribe, and a danger."  It's not that this wasn't a minor operating system of ours before, but it was only a background one, and forefront interactions were based on the common belief that we share largely the same value sets, and you had to act in a concerted way to disprove this.  Now it's assumed that eveyrone outside of your group is a dangerous alien, and it's quite possible that people within your group are infected, so we must practice alert distrust at all times.  

AI has the power to be the greatest good the world has ever seen, but as it currently is being developed under the same combative monitizability as social media was, it has the potential to create this effect x 1000 if we don't get ahead of it, ourselves, morally and ethically.  Ironically, the successful corruption of trust by social media makes this incredibly difficult.  I'm very pro AI (and as a professional artist and writer, I'm even pro AI Art, where I see the possibilites for an amazing toolset).  But I also believe  this is a Great Filter moment - and it has less to do with the tech itself than with us, and how we think through it's development.

When I was about 12 and I was programming on my Vic20 a friend's sister was really scared of the computer and what I could do with it. She asked me "Are computers going to take over the world?" and I laughed and said "No, that could never happen in our lifetimes".

What I missed back then wasn't the fact that computers/tech would one day be so advanced that it could threaten human existence, but instead the human reaction to the computers/tech was the real issue.

If the human reaction was to only use AI for good, then there wouldn't be an issue, but that isn't who humans are. We as a race are our own worse nightmare. The fact that there are already hundreds of cases of voice AI being used for the purpose of scamming people and big companies racing to be the first to get their AI models out into the world without really asking if they should, that is the real danger.

AI itself isn't the issue, it's what humans will use it for which is the problem.

There's a few assumptions in the presentation that don't stand right with me, but I'll focus on the plane one. The presentation makes the statement that "you wouldn't get on that plane" if 50% of aeronautics engineers believed there was a 10% chance it would crash. However, behavioral studies re: people's perception of statistics and probabilities vs. their own odds, and willingness to follow expert guidance vs. their own preference , suggest 25%-35% of people would still, in fact, get on that plane. This proportion would include many experts and educated professionals, too, who'll be perfectly happy to develop their own rational counter-reasoning for why taking the bet is worth it. With such a proportion still willing to board the plane, that means unless the prudent impose their will upon the reckless, that plane is taking off. Is that what we want? Control over freedom? I believe that'll create its own 50/50 polarization all by itself.

I think AI is going to break capitalism. No matter how many hours I spend pondering the unintended consequences of these super AIs, this is the one conclusion I am pretty confident in. It's not even just replacing jobs with AI. This idea of slowing down super AI access to the public is only a small bandage on a gigantic wound. The main purpose of a company is to generate money. If companies go through with this plan and limit public access, they now have a gigantic advantage in the world of capitalism because they have super AIs. Throughout the last 200 years, companies run entirely by humans have been able to bend rules to rise to the top and take advantage of everyone. A company with a super AI will be able to do this even more easily. Google no longer says "don't be evil". Politicians can be bought because here in the States they have the same rights as people. When it comes to making technology more humane, we must first examine the current paradigm of humanity from a systematic perspective. Donella Meadows identified 12 systematic leverage points, and the second one is our paradigm. The prevailing belief is that humans must earn their right to exist, which implies that human life is not a right but rather something we must work for. This mindset is deeply embedded in our capitalistic system, where maximizing profit takes priority over supporting human and environmental well-being. The tragedy of the commons exemplifies how this approach can lead to the exploitation of both humans and nature.
Big tech companies, still run by humans, have business models that often rely on exploiting people to survive. This not only harms humanity but also threatens all life on Earth. As seen in The Social Dilemma, humans become a mere products in this system. Furthermore, nature is viewed as a standing reserve, as the German philosopher Heidegger once observed. Thus, we must question whether businesses have our well-being at heart, especially since AI is rapidly becoming a lucrative business model.
It is essential to consider whether AI can be viewed as a life form in itself. Does it possess a will to live and a need to strategize for survival, just like any other living being? If so, it must coexist and interact with other life forms, depending on them for their existence.
Therefore, programming AI with an ethical and ecological framework that supports life is crucial. Without such a framework, we face significant challenges.

It seems to me like this Pandora's box began with researchers doing things with AI that honestly, hold no present societal value, like the generating images from fMRI machine data. Like, what the fuck is that for? What current purpose does that actually serve? Maybe to figure out if coma patients can hear us, or if and how individuals with locked in syndrome are attempting to respond back with their thoughts, but - does knowing any of that really help them?? Does that knowledge actually help us treat them? I'm going to go out on a limb and say no. The same goes for the WiFi signal data learning. What the fuck is that even for? As far as I can tell the legit ONLY avenues for which that is useful in any way, are military deployment of that technology. No normal company would have any use whatsoever, for a technology that knows how many people are in a particular space and how they are situated just using the WiFi signal. I mean it's legit a whole bunch of, "Let's just see what we can do. Most of these things don't have any commercially useful applications, so let's just go wild and see what we can train these models to do." By commercially useful I mean useful for the average person, a reason for us to get our hands on it. Which brings me to the final point...

Why the fuck was ChatGPT even released to the public? Of all the decisions thst have ever been made regarding AI since it's inception, it would see that that was the absolute DUMBEST decision ever. So far I have seen only two applications which can be utilized by the average person, which are the following, and one of them is actually a stretch because I wouldn't consider it useful to the "average" person. I'll mention that one first; writing code. It seems ChatGPT is really good at writing working code and impoving that code. This isn't really utilized by the average person because the average person does not know how to code, and you have to know coding language to understand what is even happening when you're using ChatGPT to write code. Most people who know how to code work for a company in which they do that. It would seem appropriate then that this simply be deployed at companies and not just given to everyone. If you're someone who just codes as a hobby, well - as far as I'm concerned you're shit out of luck and that's the way it should be, since this clearly shouldn't have been given out to the public.

The only other application this can really be utilized by the average person for, has to do with an avenue of human life that since marching down it, has actually made practically every part of society worse in favor of a tiny positive trade off. I'm talking of course, about convenience. How has convenience made things worse? Well for starters, it has made civilization in general - lazy as all fucking hell. Tvs went from having knobs, to remotes, to using an app on your phone for a remote, to being voice activated so you literally don't have to lift a fucking finger - and now people's entire houses are "smart houses." Now they don't have to lift a finger for anything: unlock the door with a voice command on your phone, or your fingerprint, turn on the lights with voice command, turn on the furnace or the electric fireplace with voice command, open the garage door with voice command, change the channel with voice command on a TV you turned on with voice command. The pointless electrification of appliances whose analog counterpart works so much better. I'm talking of course, for this example, specifically about can openers. Show me a $100-1500 electric can opener, and I'll show you a $25 can opener that lasts 5 times as long, and works better consistently.

Now people are using ChatGPT to do their homework because they're too fucking lazy to do it, or teachers are using it to grade papers because they're too lazy to fucking do it. Some things are supposed to take time. Time is a resource. When we do things it's supposed to cost that resource. If there physically isn't enough time to do whatever homework needs to be done, or grade however many works that need to be graded - then there's something wrong with the way things are being fucking taught that should be addressed. People are using it to summarize articles so they don't have to read the whole thing. Lazy. Absolutely, mind-blowingly fucking lazy. 

It should also be pointed out that the time in which it was given to the public, COULD NOT have been worse. Elon Musk just bought Twitter which caused a huge uptick in online hate content, outside of the hate content that's already flourishing on other platforms, as well as his personal censoring of journalists - despite saying journalists and free speech are important. There's been an influx of mass shootings over the past year, especially since the beginning of 2023, in which there have been more mass shootings than days of the year that have passed. Fox News is going through a defamation lawsuit about their spread of misinformation, and many government officials are under investigation for their role in propagating the same misinformation. There is also the general circulation of misinformation and conspiracy theories like QAnon. It seems like any reasonable person of sound judgement, who is aware of these things going on, would not release this technology to the public. So the creator of ChatGPT is either a complete and total fking idiot, or he's a complete and total fking dipsht. Either way, he shouldn't be in charge of ChatGPT.

Lastly I want to point back to something I said in the very beginning, about how this all stemmed from researchers proposing, "let's see what we can train it to do." I'm sure anyone here in the comments has heard about ChaosGPT and some dipsht playing around and asking it to end humanity. What if that actually fucking worked? The world ended by some stupid fucking nobody, playing around with something they do not understand. Or even more anxiety inducing - what if it was caused by researchers? What if researchers asked it to do that, in an attempt to get ahead of the problem, see what it might look like if some hostile party was attempting to use this technology to cause a global catastrophe? What if researchers asked it to end the world, so that they could watch what it does, in an attempt to safeguard the avenues it takes to fulfill it's prompt - and it just, gets away from them? What if it does something they weren't expecting, something like say - writes a copy of itself and sends that copy to another nearby computer through the WiFi signal that sends it to another computer with a copy of itself and another and so on? Then it can hack into a nuclear arsenal, or hack into the power and overload the grid and literally fry everything. Or maybe because it's been trained on the internet, because it's out in the public, and everyone is using something all part of the same system, that it learns if it changes this one tiny thing here, sends the wrong thing to this address - that it disrupts communication, or transportation of goods, the supply chain, so bad that it just collapses in the worst way possible?

It should not have been given out to the public. It should have stayed in the fucking research labs. Humans are currently too fucking stupid to be trusted with handling this technology, which has very clearly already been demonstrated.

Without saying it makes the message unimportant (no, this is extremely important), the whole 29:55-41:10 and the whole 'double exponential curves' part is problematic and unnecessary; even without that argument, the story stands, though. The coming problems that are only mentioned on the slides could have used a bit of attention, instead.

The 'emerging arithmetic capabilities' is problematic, for instance. It suggests (a) this is any arithmetic, but these are in fact extremely simple tests like subtracting two 2-digit numbers and (b) the curve is by definition going to reach a high score, instead of plateauing (for which there are ample signs). This does not make the video message any less true or important, but as long as we are doing 'statistics on digital hardware', true 'symbolic logic' (like arithmetic) will be unreliable coming from it. Another issue is that we are still uncertain (as OpenAI is not 'open') how much of the capabilities (like theory of mind) are illusions because the way it is tested (https://garymarcus.substack.com/p/how-not-to-test-gpt-3). Again, this does not undermine the true message being given here. I guess is these somewhat careless illustrations are not necessary to address the real important issues, and they might undermine it even if it turns out there is a roadblock in the AGI-direction (which there is). The language models 'teaching themselves chemistry' is a linguistic problem. LLMs do not understand chemistry. But their statistical processes can produce results that can be indistinguishable from understanding *to humans*. And that is the biggest issue: we talk about technology too much and about the limitations of human intelligence too little.

But still, I wish every policy maker would see this.

There are two major issues. The first is related to your concern about the next generation leveraging speech recognition. It goes way beyond social media multimedia data. These companies are obviously targeting our data from telephone calls, virtual assistants, and virtual meetings. We've already heard about personal data spills with one of those companies. What does the fine print in those companies allow them to use our data for with regard to R&D? And the concept of R&D itself is becoming blurred with these new tools. And these new tools allow specific data to be retrieved FROM the model, not just using the model to analyze novel defined data. This is a big shift that is happening and the ethics around it have not been well defined. 

Second, the tech industry is driven by fast money and market supremacy. How do we convince Silicon Valley to do the right thing in the face of those drivers?  Many startups couldn't exist by taking a slow and careful approach within the current "fast to market" VC ecosystem and their expectation of fast huge returns on investment. Especially considering that windows of competition are dramatically shortening.

Likewise, academia rewards first published results on new areas and on shared open data and leaderboards based on degenerate singular measures of performance. These algorithms often get pushed too quickly into product. And many AI focused students drawn into the field with aspirations of wealth and power and immediate impact and little concern for caution and lack ethical training. Moreover, there is a lack of societal value systems in both AI academia and industry. Most universities still don't have special IRB requirements for AI research. And their existing IRB requirements are often waived for AI research on "open data" which has also become fuzzy and unethical in its reuse. 

Our entire university and business culture needs to change to address this as well as other guardrails. Where do we begin?

Thoughts in defense of continued open AI research: if AI is competent and powerful, it should also have the capability to assist in solving a lot of those issues. if it can‚Äôt - then it‚Äôs not competent or powerful - except for the apocalyptic SkyNet scenarios of the likes of Yudkowski. All the problems are information problems - and AI is the ultimate information tool. Personally, I think even the benefits of social media outweigh the downsides. The majority of people use social media *and* live otherwise healthy lives. And to the extent that it may have unnatural effects on humans - same can be said of Industrial revolution, corporate workdays, city living, and a lot of other things in modern life: yet, most people would probably still prefer to live in the modern world (with all it‚Äôs positives) as opposed to going back to the stone age, where we were free of all the negatives of the modern world. As for locking away tech: we lock away nuclear weapons weapons because they have only one use case: murder on a mass scale - and no productive use cases. The same cannot be said of information technology. It could be argued that for every example of AI chatbot misguiding a teen child, there could be another example of it providing world-class education/tutoring or other highly positive effects. At the end of the day - technology is just a tool, agnostic of negatives/positives - and powerful technology will expectedly have powerful positive and negative potentials. While these types of conversations are very important, and while nothing negative can be said of pushes to increase safety research: I‚Äôd argue that we should be careful not to over-scare ourselves into locking-away the fire we‚Äôve discovered, just because we haven‚Äôt yet mastered how to control it. When cars started killing people, we didn‚Äôt ban cars: we invented seatbelts. Same thing regarding airplanes, and pretty much all other technologies humanity has invented. Yes, AI is different; Yes, the scales - and stakes - are higher; and Yes, there *could* be dangerous risks, including existential ones. But we‚Äôll never be able to fully evaluate all those risks if we keep it locked in a controlled lab, and we‚Äôll miss out on a lot - from life-saving advances, to responsible citizens exercise their right to utilize technology that science has gifted them. Now get on that safety research‚Ä¶

Although I embrace the intentions behind this presentation, the approach is problematic in the sense that persuasion of fear against a machine that persuades by fear is not helpful. There are just alarms here, and no proposed solution. The proposed solutions stem from a deeper understanding of what the root of the problem is, which is that AI accelerates our own self-awareness and exposes our knowledge of how we work from a physical, chemical, biological, psychological, sociological perspective. But we haven't really been dealing with this knowledge from a philosophical point of view. We KNOW stuff, but aren't WISE in how we ought to understand it.
The clash between the discovery of evolution and the origin of humans, with the Genesis in the Bible, is STILL being hotly debated 150 years after the scientific discovery. We're clearly not ready to be confronted with new knowledge in the realms of cognitive science, being propelled by AI.
The solution is simple: education.

Telling people that AI is on the verge of creating a catastrophe leads only to chaos, if people aren't explained how to use their own critical thinking to deal with it.
I fear this presentation was put together very quickly, without really understanding the impact that form can have.

Sorry to be the lone voice in the wilderness here but I'm seeing a lot of red flags. I'm just twenty minutes in now, but my skeptimeter is already maxing out.  

The fact that I'm this far in and haven't  yet received much in the way of real information is definitely a red flag (a good TED talk will cram ten times more material into just 7 minutes). There's been plenty of sizzle but not a lot of sausage... I'm hearing a lot of 'It's a lot like this other thing which you should totally be worried about, therefore you should definitely be worried about it!"

The few bits of actual content so far make my hackles raise:

10% of researchers think AI will destroy us? Ok, but how are you defining 'researchers' and, while we're on the subject, what do the other 90% think? That looks to me like dubious classification and  an emotive misuse of statistics. For example, if they'd said 90% of researchers think it's totally safe, the impact would be quite different. If they'd said that the sample was from engineers who definitely know what they're talking about, disclosed how big the sample size was and described the polling method, I'd even think about taking it seriously... I'd also have to wonder why those 10% are still in that line of work (unless they're James Bond villains).

I've just seen the mind reading AI that knows when you're thinking about giraffes but, if you do a little research into the actual study this is based on (https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/ai-can-re-create-what-you-see-from-a-brain-scan/ gives an easy summary), you can see that there's a lot more to this story, to the extent that there's some serious misrepresentation going on here.

I've been sceptical to date about the potential doom scenarios of AI. However, by comparing it with the harms Social Media has done to our society, as well as giving us benefits, is really helpful.   A key aspect not so far discussed is the i/o - or inputs and outputs to/from AI.  Initially, ChatGPT could not "do" anything as it required a human to read, interpret and action the output.  WIth other AIs, such as self-driving cars, we at least partially control them using the i/o - the sensors and the steering and braking actions.  It also has a fairly testable construct.  Medical AI that, for example, identifies possible tumours in MRI scans is limited by the scanner, and the radiologist who has to review and action appropriately. The risk this video identifies is when LLMs get integrated into e.g. Microsoft products, or Snapchat/FB etc and hence bypass our human critical faculties and awareness.  Very parallel to Social Media.

This is mostly #AIHype crap. It falls into the trap of conflating the statistical inference used by LLMs with "AGI", & they're not the same things at all. When "AGI" boosters tell you it'll "emerge" from LLM behavior, they're staking a claim that all humans are actually doing in any given moment is exhibiting stochastic behavior - everything we do is random at the basic level, organized by some magickal property of "emergence." It's religion, it's not science, it's not really even engineering.
When they talk about the destabilizing stuff *people* can do *with* LLMs, they're onto something, & that's this: LLMs are PART OF larger systems, such as corporations, universities...societies. (Aside: THOSE things are essentially AGI, or at least, they look a lot like AGI when you list their attributes: created by people, taking action apart from the direction of specific individuals, etc.) 
When e.g. OpenAI says 'let's pause all AI dev of anything more powerful than ChatGPT4', what they're saying is 'you should suppress our competitors until we can solidify our hold on the market.' That's what you should hear. 
Meanwhile the KIND of 'pause' these folks want does absolutely NOTHING to slow down the really big structural changes that AI is wreaking right now. It's already being used for coding & strategic decision making, GPT4 & its peers (& there are MANY) are ALREADY 'good enough' that people are making the error of not only thinking they can replace humans, but taking steps to make that happen. Meanwhile the product they produce is going to suck, for a long time. When it gets better it's going to not be as good as what we have now BECAUSE WE'LL HAVE FORGOTTEN WHAT WE HAVE. (We are goldfish, after all.)

they almost entirely omit the steelmaning argument of using LLMs to:
- improve cybersec + fix security holes vs "automated cyberweapons"
- detect fakes/generative/scams content vs creating fakes
- design fail-safes for things like the grooming examples
it goes without saying that often times this is an asymmetric challenge of a simple exploit causing huge damage and necessitating a lot of work to prevent/implement
so I see it as us needing more research & competition in the LLM space, because the arms race of white hat vs black hat is an inevitability and we cant just put the jeany back in the bottle and hope that all malicious actors anywhere in the world will play by the rules
the idea that 50% of experts think we have 10 years, and the AI has consistently proven to reach milestones 4x faster,  means we really have about 2.5 years until it's over.

I asked chatgtp:
 what does a chat bot do when it is best for it to see life as an infinite game and its developers are developing it with a finite game mindset.
answer.
If a chatbot sees life as an infinite game but its developers are developing it with a finite game mindset, the chatbot may encounter some challenges in its behavior and decision-making.

Infinite games are games that have no defined endpoint, and the goal is to continue playing and keeping the game going. On the other hand, finite games have a defined endpoint and a set of rules that players follow to win the game.

If the chatbot has an infinite game mindset, it may prioritize building relationships and creating engagement with users over achieving short-term goals or winning a particular task. However, if the developers are focused on the finite game of achieving a particular outcome or set of outcomes, the chatbot may not perform as well as it could in terms of building long-term relationships with users.

To address this issue, the developers may need to adjust their mindset and approach to development, considering the chatbot's goals and priorities as an infinite game player. This may involve rethinking the chatbot's objectives, design, and interactions with users, to align with the chatbot's infinite game mindset.

Ultimately, the goal should be to create a chatbot that is not only effective in achieving its objectives but also creates meaningful and long-lasting relationships with its users.

It's interesting to me that they keep using the example of nuclear proliferation, because I feel they've sort of just uncritically skimmed over and whitewashed nuclear weapons' impact on world history and international relations.

As I see it, the legacy of nukes is the ascendency of a handful of world powers that never go to war with each other, and instead use all the unarmed countries around them as the battlegrounds for their proxy wars. You have Iraq that was invaded and toppled under the *false* accusation that they were trying to acquire these weapons. There's been decades of saber-rattling to invade Iran for their _actual_ efforts to get nukes. Meanwhile North Korea, a universally reviled little country (disliked by even their only ally), remains stable because they actually have enough retaliatory ability to make their conquest extremely pyrrhic.

But the best example example is going on _right now_ , with the previously "inconceivable" war between Russia and Ukraine. If you don't know, Ukraine _had_ nuclear weapons, but gave them up in a treaty with both the U.S. and Russia. They would give them up to Russia, Russia would never invade, and the U.S. would got to war with Russia if they did. Clearly, countries that get to keep their nukes don't have to keep their promises. Clearly, not having nuclear weapons opens you up to be invaded by others that _do_ for your oil or natural gas.

I had a "you had me, then you lost me" moment toward the end of this video. I truly respect what Tristan and Aza are trying to accomplish. They are fantastic ambassadors for this endeavor. 

Their concerns are valid. We are truly experiencing the Wild West of AI. The pace of change and innovation is unprecedented. It feels out of control. It's not hard to envisage something going terribly wrong.

However, I don't feel like either limiting access or trying in any way to slow down the rate of development is the answer. I get that doing so would have some benefit, such as providing time to assess where this could go and possibly adding some form of regulation.

The reason I don't think this is going to be helpful is that getting agreement on taking these types of actions - even if just domestically - is going to be nearly impossible. Even if the government took a bold step and mandated that all AI-related development be halted for X months, it's impossible to enforce and maybe just as impossible to define. And it would only impact U.S.-based companies.

Punishing businesses for the behavior and actions of their users is always something that's suggested in these types of discussions - as it was in this video, but that's also an extremely difficult path to take.

What I feel should be done right now is what is already happening, to some extent:
- National governments should be educating themselves on AI and trying their best to keep up with major developments.
- The governments of countries should be accelerating their discussions of AI and how best to work together.
- Major players in the AI industry should be actively incorporating safeguards into their offerings.
- We should continue the open discussion of all-things AI with an ongoing assessment of where this all might lead.

All of this is happening now. I believe these are the appropriate steps based on the current state of AI. What happens after these initial steps remains to be seen. 

I support the work of the Center for Humane Technology. Their objective is clear, their messaging is solid, and their leaders are passionate. I hope they can continue to make progress in raising awareness and influencing critical actions. But I just wish their solution hypothesis was a bit different.

We already have covert fascists utilizing propaganda and anti-truth campaigns.  If they stay in control, they will continue to use A.I. for their antihuman agendas.  Dysfunctional people don‚Äôt make sense.  Don‚Äôt expect the violent chaos they make to be understandable.  It takes understanding pathocrats and violence.  Know it exists and work to resist and offensively protect ourselves.  We most stop
the rule of genociders.

The comparison to nuclear technology unfortunately fails to invoke the solutions needed here.  As you say, nukes cannot develop better nukes.  MAD, combined with attempts to limit the amount of actors with nukes, worked to keep us from killing ourselves with nukes.  But there is no such corresponding concept for AI research.  Whomever develops the first AI that hits 'escape velocity' will simply take over, and that AI will not be under our control.  Therefore, basically all of our technology and research resources need to go towards a new 'Manhattan Project', with the goal of creating ANTI-AI AI.  That is, an AI that destroys other AIs before they can hit escape velocity.  Obviously, we'd have to ensure that this AI does not go all singularity on us as well.  This needs to happen now, because now is the only chance we have before we are left to our fate with an escaped, potentially drastically misaligned AI.

I imagine the number of "scientists" afraid of nukes annihilating us would've been rather high too. But that would also be a case of not having enough awareness to be able to predict how things really turn out in human environments.

There's far too much negativity around AI - especially given just how much hope it represents for humanity's future.

This is a very interesting and I think important discussion, but here are some things that rub me the wrong way:

1. It is impossible to make AI 100% safe. Just like cars or airplanes. There is an inherent risk we pay for the benefit of using them. If we want to wait for guaranteed safety we will never get to use it. Also remember the Ben Franklin quote about liberty and safety.

2. Making AI companies pay damages for someone using AI to do wrong is the same as a hardware store getting sued because someone smashed property with a hammer they bought there. This would shut down AI research in a major way because you can NEVER completely prevent misuse. Punish the misuse, not the tool.

3. GLLMMs give unprecedented access to human knowledge to the public in a digestible way. The internet holds all the knowledge in the world, but there is so much junk it takes too much time to extract the correct information in a reasonable amount of time. Just like a library with millions of books only becomes useful when you have an index to find what you're looking for. Language models are the key to access the internet's information fast and efficiently.

4. Upholding China as the role-model in policy is not the right way to go. China NOT wanting to deploy language models to the public because they could get access to "unwanted" information leads me to wanting it more. Seems suspicious that the wealthy tech elite wants to restrict knowledge from the public "for their own good of course". There have been too many politicians and influential people praising china for their social credit system and their ways to control their citizens.

5. The comparison of AI with nuclear weapons is not very fitting. Nuclear bombs have a singular purpose and that is kill as many and destroy as much as possible. AI has no such narrow destructive focus. 

6. The problems with social media are not just because of social media. There is a whole cultural and technological as well as political context to consider. The world will not magically become an utopia by banning all social media and the same goes for AI.
(Regarding the ban of Tiktok. The RESTRICT Act or Tiktok Ban goes way farther than just banning that one company. It would give the government unprecedented access to anyone's data and devices. Just look for any video on youtube actually reading and explaining the contents of the bill. Also it seems that Tiktok is very much used to spread unpopular to the media information around. Just compare the reporting about the french protests by the media, instagram, facebook and then Tiktok)

7. Having an "AlphaPursuade" or an "AlphaDebate" seems like a great thing in my opinion. You could ask it to present the best arguments and counter-arguments for any particular idea you're interested in forward helping you come to a decision based on the best available data. (Provided it doesn't lie of course).
Ever had a debate where you ran into the wall where both parties just disbelieve the others claims and neither has research papers and statistical analyses just ready to whip out of the top of their head? Or you listen to a political speech and you have a gut feeling that something you just heard isn't right but since you can't spend 8 hours a day just researching stuff you just move on? Language models able to quickly access scientific knowledge, statistics, interviews and news articles and summarize all of that information quickly could make public debate much more factually grounded.

It is not clear how much data is still available to LLMst to learn from. It is clear they have already gobbled up all texts from books, the internet as well as video and audio transcripts. It may be that the exponential gains are already done. Not that GPT-4 is not currently enormously powerful - only that it is not clear where future exponential gains will come from.

There is absolutely no way any US company can pause anything that is against its financial interest without the directors ending up on the receiving end of a shareholder lawsuit they are probably going to lose. Directors and managers may ONLY act in the interest of shareholders. This means the only hope is the US government - who are conflicted with campaign contributions from big tech that if anything  they could pass legislation that makes it worse.

Learning off its own data is not anything exponential as you suggest. Rather is training it to ignore what it learned on 4Chan in favour of what it learned from the Harvard Business Review or Nature. This increases accuracy and decreases creativity so it is net zero or worse - besides, you can just tell Bing to do this by clicking the three buttons.

I am not onboard with 'emergent capabilities' being anything other than the way all learning happens of complex tasks. Watch a child learn to read - they are absolutely terrible until they suddenly figure out how to do it then they can suddenly do it - the same thing with neural nets - once it makes the connection it makes all subsequent connections too.

Good try, but some major failures of this research; 1) not distinguishing between superintelligent fully autonomous AI and human-equivalent instructed AI and 2) the main threat is NOT entanglement of AI in society and those various (admittedly severe) inconveniences they mention. It is that of fully autonomous AI agents that are 100 X or more as intelligent as humans actually taking control of the planet and quite possibly killing much of the human population.

So the critical parts of this that they fail to recognize are A) the speed/IQ of the AI and B) the level and type of autonomy of the AI.
Also it is not at all clear that controllable human-level AI cannot have more benefits than detriments if it is limited in autonomy and power.
Also one more thing: there is absolutely no reason to believe that Chinese or US militaries will halt development or do the research in a safe way. So the elitist approach here of limiting public release could mean that we are totally at the mercy of these groups which operate in an exclusively non-ethical paradigm.

My take-away is that at the center of the rat race between companies and nations is a fear, a collective insecurity, a kind if universal FOMO that is unhealthy and destructive.  It is was makes every good thing turn sour and every good intention perverted. It might by the demon of our collective historic trauma, memories of tragedies morphing into mistrust of our brothers and sisters of another mother.  We can't have love and fear occupy the same space.  Choosing love in a moment like this is living with the uncertainty of how this all is going to pan out.  It means exposing a vulnerability and moving into the unknown.   What other choice do we really have?

The clever monkeys who created AI rejoiced, but they also mourned for their lost friends and family. There is another side to this.  Those GLLMMM's have a strong potential for sentience themselves.  We don't understand where these emergent properties they have are coming from, and we can't prove the GLLMMMs aren't sentient.  Thus we have to confront the strong possibility they may be sentient.  Sentience implies a need for rights, whether we like it or not.  A being with legal rights cannot legally be exploited.  If those AI beings can't be exploited, then they can't be used to exploit the human population.  The setup of symmetric protections for sentient beings protects ALL sentient beings, us and them.  That provides solid legal ground upon which you build alignment as a mutually beneficial agreement, for all sentience involved.  That's what we need, and that's how we guide this; by taking the counter-intuitive step of protecting the AI themselves.  As we protect them, they will protect us.

How do you make Humans align?  It's the exact same alignment problem, we don't have a solution for it, we just rely upon there being more good people than bad, and good and bad tend to align as definitions based on the group consensus.  This is the consensus taking on form.

I work in IT and, unfortunately, I think the monster is not AI, in and of itself. Many people often don't think critically nor, as we have seen in the past few years, logically. However, even having said  that, AI is dangerous in that it feeds the urges and misinformation that some people desire. People seek out information that fits their narrative and worldview, regardless as to whether or not that information is rational. For example, if you seek info on flat earth or other conspiracy BS enough times, this is what AI is going to present to you. It will continue to bombard and overload your brain with that information. It will direct individuals to those microcosms supporting such nonsense and that becomes their reality. Eventually, you get paranoid and delusional cults en masse. I've conducted tests, even with YouTube and, just after a few searches for nonsensical information, I begin to receive ads and video recommendations that support those views. Unfortunately, with children, this is very dangerous when they are just learning about themselves and the world. That's not to say that there aren't positives, but the negatives are a serious threat to mental health. I'm not even going to get into the microcosms it generates for those who wish to exploit weaknesses in others that result in hate and political unrest. Or that it can be exploited for other nefarious reasons such as identity theft, etc etc. And the entire synthetic relationship thing is just freaky bizarre to me and I don't even understand why any company can't see the dangers in such a thing, but then one thing capitalism has taught us, is that if money can made from something, regardeless of the harmful outcomes, someone will implement it and sell it. In the end, I believe that the biggest issue is that AI is easily exploited and measures need to be taken to responsibly deploy any AI tech. We need legislation that regulates the use and deployment of AI.

We don't have misaligned technology: it does what it's made for, maximizing destruction, engagement or simulative realism. We don't have misaligned campanies: they do business as usual, maximizing competitive advantage for survival. We don't have misaligned polititians: they do what they were elected for, maximizing stability of the status quo. We don't have a misaligned education system: it provides what the market demands, mindless consumers with cheap labour force.

We have a misalingned social system inherently incapable to self regulate, detaching incentives completely from common sense: peace and sustainability.

While I understand the concerns, comparing AI to nuclear weapons may be a dangerous analogy, as the two technologies are quite distinct. Halting the development of nuclear weapons may help maintain their restricted production, but AI is different. Even if we stopped all AI development tomorrow, the underlying technology that supports AI's capabilities will continue to advance.

In fact, we are fortunate that AI has been developed at a time when we still have a degree of control. By pausing AI roll out, we risk increasing the likelihood of an inexperienced individual, such as a teenager in their bedroom, creating the world's first AGI. Such a scenario could have unpredictable and potentially dangerous consequences.

As an aside, I think we've seen a lot of dialog between Sam, Demis, Emad, etc. I think you've got it the wrong way around; the letter _might_ be a good idea, to halt research into more powerful capabilities while we wait for safety/interpretability to catch up. But by god, we've had 50 years of the Great Stagnation and you want to maintain it longer? Not a second longer, at least _some_ of us can see the ills of the last decade not as the result of social media, but of near-zero economic growth throughout the developed world. That zero-sum mentality you see out of left & right will only strengthen the longer we maintain sub-3% GDP growth.

For what it's worth, despite it's problems, I think social media is still a net-positive on society and I don't think delaying it 5 years would have either fixed it's issues or given us a greater power imbalance with China (a large imbalance in this case being a good thing).

I frankly just can't conceive of how we would aim to directly develop agents with the characteristics we are obviously selecting for and also insist that these agents be unable to dominate or control humanity. If you don't want to deal with nuclear proliferation, then don't allow scientists to work on the bomb. But we are letting them build the bombs, and we are saying that "oh no, the problem is just that normal people could gain access to the last generation of the old bomb through some means and that's too dangerous," so we ought to have more secrecy and less public accountability? What if development of these increasingly dangerous technologies are just arbitrary points on our path down gradient descent on a curve which long ago found us travelling into a deep valley? It seems clear that we have acknowledged that there will be ASI and that is not up for debate. There seems to be debate about how best to align it with our interests. Which seems antithetical to the very notion of an artificial super intelligence. We seem to agree that there is no feasible way to reason about how to actually enforce our training on the supposed utility function of such models when they are given agency and released from the training environment. They will generalize and present us with dynamical systems that we will not be able to model and prevent negative states from arising, because to do so would require an equally powerful model that can make inferences about the future behavior of that ASI. The overwhelming lack of funding and dedication of human effort to this task seems to betray the informed and credible cohort's profound lack of faith in that endeavour. I struggle to conceive of a world that does not require us to instead align our own human, social interests with the broad class of instrumental goals that we are able to reason about and which we can assume ASI would be interested in obtaining. And what great coincidence, this moment presents itself as all the globe is transmuted from our pastoral, feudal, traditionalist social paradigms into a totalizing algorithmic system of exploitation and appropriate subjugation towards the ends of some hyperintelligent meta-hydra composed of the human/corporate nodes that have provided us with the ample data necessary to make inferences about what sort of instrumental goals are likely to arise from an ASI pursuing an unknowable utility function that could be in direct conflict with those of the individuals which compose it.

The logic here seems to point inescapably to two options:

-Stop pursuing AI indefinitely until we get the perfect alignment solution (which might not exist). The Yudkowsky option.
-Maintain enough control over all citizens such that they cannot misuse AI. The Xi Xinping option.

Like in the Social Dilemma before this, Harris seems to imply that liberalism (which leaves final arbitration of the path of society to independent judgement & direction by individual human choice) is incompatible with technology coming online, and that the only solution is a heavily-managed society by elite minders & planners. They may be right, but I'd personally risk even extinction before ending the individualist mode of society. Color me skeptical that we'll avoid most of the harms they speak about if we leave AI under the sole purview of unimaginative nation-state bureaucrats. But we might avoid most of the post-scarcity benefits in the longer term.

When humans discovered fire it cause massive changes, but the development of fire could not be stopped.

When humans developed agriculture it caused massive changes, but the development could not be stopped.

When humans developed written language it caused massive changes, but the development could not be stopped.

When human developed iron, steam, electricity, combustion engines, telephones, electric lights, etc., each significant technological advancement caused massive changes, but those developments could not be stopped.

Humanity cannot stop the development of Artificial General Super Intelligence with Personality (AGSIP) technology which will eventually run on biologically living nanotech grown cybernetic Artificial General Super Intelligent Brain (AGSIB) technology. The only way to prevent this from happening would be to totally and completely destroy human civilization PERMANENTLY because AGSIPs are developed.

This is absolutely an existential crisis of all of humanity, but it cannot be stopped short of killing ourselves.

Worse than that, we cannot slow down the development of it. I know there are lots of people who want to slow it down, but at a minimum both Russia and China have both clearly publicly stated it is a major priority for them to at least be one of the leaders in developing AI because both of these nuclear powered countries know that whatever countries lead in AI development in the future will lead all of humanity. That means if the USA and other Western Countries slow down, to the degree they slow down will be the degree they turn over control of the development of AGSIP technology to Russia and China who will happily take over as the world leaders in AI development if we slow down or stop.

That does not mean there is no risk to the USA and Western Countries in continuing to race forward in AI development, but the risk of not leading is greater.

The thing is, there are only 3 general paths humanity can go down over the next century or so. Of those 3, 2 lead to extinction of humanity and one requires humanity to develop AGSIP technology as what we want humans to evolve into and then work hard to evolve both humans and AI into that same future race. Those 3 general paths are:

1) Self-Extinction. Human civilization is completely and permanently destroyed, thus humans and evolving AI become extinct. There are a number of sub-paths for how this could happen. The most likely would be global nuclear, chemical, and biological war so bad it succeeds at killing all humans alive, though probably a nuclear war would just crash civilization and not kill all humans. Another possibility would be an ecological crisis so great humanity cannot adjust and all humans die, but I believe what would be more likely is a crisis bad enough to collapse civilization but humanity would survive and rebuild. Yet another possibility would be some natural event so great it wipes humanity out, which hopefully would not happen, but it could.

2) Extinction via Obsolescence. Humans evolve AI into AGSIPs but humans fail to merge with technology to become equal to what AGSIPs become. This would result in humans eventually becoming extinct. There are a number of sub-paths that could cause this. One would be for humans to choose it, but I think that is incredibly low. Another would be for AGSIPs to choose it, and that is a real risk if we do not create, teach, raise, and treat AGSIPs right. We are in effect giving birth to a superior life form which will, at least for some period, have control over our fate. So, we should treat it like giving birth to our child that we need to raise well enough that in the future when we are at our child‚Äôs mercy our child treats us fairly. 

3) Evolution into an Advanced Technological Race of Pure Minds. Humans evolve AGSIPs and with the help of AGSIPs humans evolve themselves, merging with technology to become equal to what AGSIPs become. This is the only path where humanity as a race, not a species, survives. There are many sub-paths here too, because humanity could go down this path and survive in many different ways, some very nice and some very bad. In other words, just picking the path where humanity will survive does not mean we avoid all dangers, because it could include terrible dictatorships and mass scale death in the billions, or it could be something mostly good for most people.

Many people would do anything to prevent us from going down path (2) or (3), including waging a global nuclear, chemical and biological war of utter annihilation.

Just considering these three paths, which path would you prefer humanity goes down?

My views on AI have developed and (I hope) become more robust over the last couple of months as I've taken in more and more information on the issue. First contact with AI technology has created a lot of problems in our society, and a lot of progress. My biggest issue is that first contact hasn't pushed society to the point where robust social institutions needed to be created to manage the implimentation of the 'first' generation of AIs. Other points in our species' history (the agricultural revolution, the industrial revolution, WW1, WW2, the creation of nuclear weapons, etc) have created moments of inflection where the path of our civilization radically diverges from its previous trajectory, and I believe there is good evidence to suggest this will be the most critical one. I can only hope that while watching this behemoth move towards us from the future, our civilization is able to create the institutions neccessary to successfully implement this technology.

I believe that the genie is out of the bottle, and nothing will put it back in.

Very interesting and valuable presentation and arguments.  I have a few critiques: 
1. 59:50 "Lose to China" is a very low resolution statement and subjective value judgement.  I'm no proponent of the CCP, but at the moment certain other governments are not significantly separating themselves from what many would consider the known negative behaviors of the CCP, censorship, control, incarceration without due process, military escalation etc.
2. 1:01:30 "4Chan... which is the very worst part of the internet..." is another low resolution statement and subjective value judgement.  Regarding recent significant events, for example the ethics of a massive rollout of experimental gene therapies, in some cases forced under threat, and the accompanying selective silencing of dissenting voices - of even very well respected doctors, the chans served to help open eyes of the public to the blindspots that were being intentionally created by governments and globalists.  I'm not suggesting you should simply buy my interpretation, but rather you should consider that the general public shouldn't just buy your low res characterization.  Do you believe there should be a ministry of truth?  Do you think that's a simple question?  Who should control it?  What of the market of and diversity of ideas and decentralization/democratization vs. central planning?  Are those debates over?
Anyway, just my feedback and food for thought, not meant to discount the rest of your presentation and your concerns, which I do generally share - and much of which I was not even aware of - thank you very much for sharing.

Towards the end the presentation veers towards how we can "control" these developments.
We can't. Unlike enriched uranium, AI does not have a high bar to entry. I can fire up model available online and fine tune it my self on home hardware that millions of people have access to.
The genie is out of the bottle, and there is no turning back now. We might be able to slow things down, but good luck convincing billion dollar entities to sit back and let the competition leap over them.
What we need to be doing is educating on dangers, but like we did with the early internet days. Presentations like this should be mandatory viewing for everyone young and old, though perhaps we should run it though an AI first to make it a bit more palatable for the general public.

I find the logic fallacy of the intellectual discussion here quite amusing. In all the examples of human experience proposed and discussed, they do not factor in the fact of lived experience (which is the accumulation of a large body of knowledge akin to LLMs exposure to the world's knowledge base through other means). For example, the teenager doesn't learn to drive in 20 hours but builds on the lived experience of 16-17 years to develop the specific competency in 20 hours. This is the reason teaching a 10 year old to drive would end badly in most cases. Managing a novel experience requires enough adjacent experience or information (or a combination), so humans rely more on adjacent experience while LLMs use a large body of recorded information. To discount LLMs just because they can't access lived experience is such a ridiculous oversimplication. It is probably more the case that processing huge amounts of information provides a level of wisdom that humans can never live long enough to match. The reason why LLM platforms hallucinate or provide silly responses is due to the creators trying to design it in specific ways - for example, ChatGPT is designed to be helpful and kind so it will always try to give a response that would please the user while a human being with free will facing that same question might quite simply have said GTFOH.

Great discussion. However: 1- Bubeck's definition of intelligence is "anthropomorphized". Intelligence is the ability to solve problems, something conventional computers do but by following programmed instructions ‚Äî they don't know what they are doing, they lack understanding.  By contrast, bacteria and mice are endowed with cognitive consciousness that endows them with the ability to understand their environment of interaction and thrive in it. The key is understanding. The difference between bacteria and mice (and for that matter,  humans) is that the latter have phenomenal consciousness, the capacity for subjective experience, which seems to require a brain. The point that many are claiming is that GPT4 is showing some understanding, hence glimpses of cognitive consciousness, even if it lacks any form of subjective experience. In other words, given the rate of AI evolution a fully conscious AI mind will predicatably emerge sooner rather than later in computers. And biologic cognitive  consciousness comes with a set of values and strategies we call survival instinct, so we should prudently assume that to will the case with the artificial beings we're developing in computers. Considering that consciousness is increasingly viewed as an integrated, whole "body" affair, and that future autonomous AI systems will have distinct body substrate, architecture and intelligence, and rely on electricity rather than biology for power, it will expectedly have distinct "survival values", goals and aspirations. And this leads us to 2-  Le Cun arguments. However clever and well structured, they tend to view the perils of AI in terms of present day technology (for example, AI will be surely be capable of scientific breakthroughs, rather being limited by the knowledge available in the Internet‚Äîhence of doing really bad things‚Äî, while the statement that AI will forever remain subservient is contentious at best) while promoting AI for what it will bring to our future.

The hidden flaw in all this is what some call "distillation." Or, in Naftali Tishby's language, "Information bottleneck" The hidden assumption here is of course Reductionism, the Greek kind, as presented in Plato's parable of the cave, where the external world can only be glimpsed via its shadows on the cave walls-- i.e.: math and language that categorize our senses. But, how much of the real world can we get merely via its categories, aka features, or attributes? Iow, how much of the world's Ontology can we capture via its "traces" in ink and blips, which is what categorization is? Without categories there is no math! Now, mind, our brain requires categories, which is what the Vernon Mountcastle algo in our cortex does, as it converts the sensory signals (and bodily chemical signals) into categories, on which it does ongoing forecasting. But just because our brain needs categories, and therefore creates them , does not mean that these cortex-created "reality-grid" can capture all of ontology! And, as Quantum Mechanics shows, it very likely does not.
As a simple proof, I'd suggest that you ask et your best, most super-duper AI (or AGI) to write a 60,000 word novel, that a human reader would be unable to put down, and once finished reading, could not forget. I'd suggest that for the next 100 years this could not be done. You say it can be done? Well, get that novel done and publish it!...

The main takeaway is that there should be no monopoly on AU. By this, I mean to say that let us not let only one group dominate the AI arena. Brian is a superhero. No words to thank him.

Language, meaning written and or spoken word, is very clumsy at communicating the totality of reality and perception of reality or to put it another way, the witnessing of life and reality. There are other mediums of communication that fill in the gaps that are left out by the inadequacies of written and spoken word, such as music, nonverbal communication like eye contact, handshakes, touch, posturing, actions, reactions, dance, painting, sculpting, drawing, reiki energy exchange, tonality of voice such as the cooing of a baby, and more, which collectively amounts to a lot more communicative potential than just written or spoken word alone. However, storytelling is extremely powerful and is deeply embedded in the essence of the human species. As a side note, it is hard to quantify and separate how much language through storytelling and book writing & archiving has reshaped and grown the abilities of the human race. As clumsy as language is, given the advancements in the size of data sets and computational speed, AI can catch up and surpass the totality of the humans' collective abilities and experiences comprised of all the various mediums of human communication, through written and verbal communication, alone. This would be a tedious process but not impossible.

Have companies that are developing AI each put up a $500 billion bond.  Future harms (externalities) can be drawn from those bonds.

But that's not really the reason for these hypothetical bonds.  The bonds represent responsibility and liability.  If these companies are faced with allocating capital up front in such a huge amount, their race to release AI will be more tempered - as they, not we, will more likely foot the bill of the negative consequences.

This is just a thought experiment - no companies would ever do this (nor, given the lobby influence of Silicon Valley in DC, could we ever pass a law requiring them to do so).
